characters: FILLING THE SCREEN, WIPING US TO
THE CAMERA TRACKS AROUND HIM, REVEALING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glory of stratospheric dawn.  The engines of a silver Lockheed U-2F rasp upon the trace oxygen here at 72,500 f Scattered cloud formations hang over the blue brilliance sea far, far below.  In the haze, the looming edge of lan SUPER: FLIGHT G-3101. OCTOBER 14TH, 1962. OVER CUBA. The spy plane's CAMERA DOORS whine open.  The glassy eye the 36-inch camera focuses.  And then with a BANGBANGBANGBANG, its high-speed motor kicks in, shutter flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple CAMERA, snapping away furiously in the hands of giggling MARK O'DONNELL, 4.  He's straddling and in the f of his dad, KENNY O'DONNELL, 30's, tough, Boston-Irish, w a prodigious case of morning hair.  Kenny awakens, red-ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, get off your father! Kenny sits up to the morning bedlam of the O'Donnell hous KIDS screech, doors bang all over.  Kenny pushes Mark ove rolls out of bed, snatches up the corners of the blanket hoists Mark over his shoulder in a screaming, kicking bun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, with Mark in the bundle on his shoulder, meets his wife HELEN going the other way in the hall with LITTLE HE 1, in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, hon. They kiss in passing.  Daughter KATHY, 12, races by in an pursuit of her twin, KEVIN, 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget, Mrs. Higgins wants to talk to you this afternoon about Kevin.  You need to do something about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids are supposed to get detention. Kenny dumps the bundle with Mark in a big pile of dirty laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of massive FILM CANISTERS unlock and drop from the belly of the U-2.  TECHNICIANS secure them in orange carr cases, lock them under key, fast and proficient.  They wh them out from under the spy plane. The Technicians run for an idling Jeep.  They sling the c into the rear of the vehicle which in turn accelerates aw hard, curving across the runway for another waiting plane

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kitchen out of the late 1950's.  Kenny drinks coffee, t a tie, rifles through a briefcase at the kitchen table. horde of kids, ages 2-14, breakfast on an array of period food.  Kenny grills the kids while he goes over papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secretary of Defense...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean Rusk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong, and you get to wax my car. KENNY JR. smirk at Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusk is State, moron.  Robert McNamara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got time for pancakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Attorney General? A PHONE RINGS as the kids cry out en masse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chorus)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too easy!  Bobby, Bobby Kennedy! Kenny glances up at the wall.  There are two phones, side side.  One RED, one BLACK.  It's the black one ringing.  Helen answers.  Kenny goes back to his papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, wise guys, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A U.S. Navy truck lurches to a stop in front of the run-d brick-faced seven-story Steuart Building on 5th and K.  R doors BANG open, and out hop two MARINE GUARDS, side arms drawn, film canisters in a carrying case between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Marines approach the building, front doors SLAM op

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bespectacled OPERATIONS MANAGER hands a clipboard to on the big Marine Guards who in turn hands him a set of keys The Manager unlocks the film cases.  PHOTO INTERPRETERS s in, whisk away the contents: SPOOLS OF FILM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black Lincoln pulls away from the modest white house on tidy Washington D.C. residential street.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The car threads its way through the Washington traffic, p the big administrative buildings, down tree-lined avenues takes a turn into a gate.  As the car stops at the gate, CAMERA flies past, revealing it's the gate to the WHITE HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the five-thousand rolls of film spewing through processing equipment, its streaking passage leading us straight through the development machinery to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Photo Interpreters power up light tables, stereoscopic viewers, zip across the floor in wheeled chairs. Flying switches, flickering lights, humming motors.  It's eerie dance of technological black magic. Another pair of Interpreters loom out of the darkness, si by side, ghostly looking, their glasses reflecting the gl of the light table, like magicians staring into a crystal ball.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGES FILL THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Aerial shots, flashing by.  Cuban countryside from 72,500 feet.  A MAGNIFYING GLASS swings down on its arm in front us, magnifying the carpet of trees... and a row of six ca covered OBJECTS among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, in business suit and tie, trots up the steps, and MARINE GUARD snaps the door open for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, briefcase in hand, weaves his way through the empt ornate hallways of the West Wing.  Past magnificent doorw early American furniture, paintings.  He finally reaches doorway, goes through into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, narrow affair, window at the back looking out int the Rose Garden.  Kenny dumps his briefcase on the desk, shucks off his coat, removes a folder from his briefcase, turns and heads back out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And into the warren of offices and halls that is the work White House.  He takes a right, passes the doors to the O Office right next to his office, goes down a long, straig hall, into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The formal main building, the executive mansion.  He pass the busts of Presidents past, turns left into an elevator The doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open.  Kenny strides out onto a DIFFERENT FLOOR the third.  He heads down the long, posh hall of the fami quarters.  Fine furnishings, art.  The living White House He approaches the double doors at the end of the hall gua by a cluster of SECRET SERVICE AGENTS.  An agent opens on the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Floyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. O'Donnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny enters the elegant bedroom.  The figure alone at a table by the window, drinks coffee, breakfast still sprea out before him, Washington Post obscuring his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top o' the morning, Mr. President. The figure lowers the paper. It is PRESIDENT JOHN F. KENNEDY.  He's wearing boxers and tank top.  Unshaven.  Bed-head. Kenny O'Donnell, former ward-pol and long-time Kennedy ma is his Chief of Staff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Kenny.  You see this goddamn Capehart stuff? The President rattles the paper.  Kenny collapses in the chair opposite the President, sprawls, comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bayh's going to lose, but it's good groundwork for us for '64. Kenny steals a piece of buttered toast off the President' plate.  The President spares him a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was eating that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you weren't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scanning the paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was, you bastard. Kenny takes a defiant bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what've we got today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, for your information, is Pulaski Day.  We're going to Buffalo...

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: A luxury hotel crowded with LOCAL POLS: the Democratic machine of Buffalo.  Beyond the open floor-to-ceiling windows, a CROWD.  The Pulaski Day Parade, a glimpse of ' Americana.  High School bands blare Sousa.  The scene is deafening, boisterous.  Pols trail Kenny as he crosses th room: fast, tough, on-the-go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're putting up Potowski next time.  Will you guys come out for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's Richardson.  Good kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got the touch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Still moldable, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone likes a good kid... And like that, a congressional candidate is made...  Kenn accelerates, leaving the Pols behind.  Suddenly, outside windows, the crowd swells forward with a collective ROAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny heads down the steps with New York Times Washington Bureau Chief, SCOTTY RESTON. Anonymous, they weave their through the crowd for a police car on a side street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's my favorite President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy.  But you've got his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want an hour with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said his heart, not his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three weeks before midterm elections?  You need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  There is a new civil rights initiative he wants to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing a piece on Skybolt.  I hear Macmillan's meeting with him in Nassau. Kenny just sighs as they make their way up to the police A Secret Service Agent opens the door for him, another is behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're giving the Brits Polaris instead.  But a story'll just aggravate things. Scotty stares at Kenny, determined.  Kenny looks away.  A his eye catches a tall, willowy BEAUTIFUL WOMAN.  She is talking, excited, embarrassed, to two more SECRET SERVICE AGENTS.  What they're saying is lost in the noise. Scotty follows Kenny's gaze.  Then the two men share a lo a silent understanding.  Kenny glances at the Secret Serv guy holding the car door, tilts his head at the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not today.  He's got tight schedule. The Agent nods, heads for the other Agents and the Beauti Woman.  Scotty acts like nothing has happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretending there isn't a problem won't fix it.  He can clear the air on Anglo American relations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, Scotty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him talk to me, he makes Macmillan look good, I print it, the British public likes it, Macmillan owes you. The formula's exactly what Kenny wants to hear.  He prete to consider, pretends to cave as he gets in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you're in.  Half hour. Reston's won.  But so has Kenny, and he's made Scotty fee tough in the bargain.  People like Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back seat, Kenny stares out the window at the para goers.  The Secret Service Agents leave the Woman.  Disappointed, the Woman turns and vanishes into the crowd It's an eerie moment.  Something troubles Kenny, and he glances up at the sky.  A premonition.  But it's a clear, clear blue.  A day like this, all is right with the world

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six Interpreters huddle around IMAGES on a light table. of them shoulders his way into the group and THUMPS a bla BINDER on the table.  There are grim nods of agreement. The book is open to a PICTURE of an SS-4 BALLISTIC MISSIL A photo from Moscow Mayday parade.  An icon of the nuclea age escorted like some devil-god to a holocaust...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White House casts long shadows this gorgeous October morning.  Blue sky; the first flash of color in the trees SUPER: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 16TH, 1962.  DAY 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briefcase and coat in hand, Kenny enters his office - and finds THREE MEN.  Standing there.  Thin-haired, bespectac academic-looking MCGEORGE BUNDY, 43, the National Securit Advisor.  The two men in the background: PHOTO INTERPRETE Kenny hangs up his coat, sees the Interpreters' large bla display cases.  And suddenly the world is slightly off kilter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mac.  You're up bright and early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ken.  I need to see him now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny emerges from the elevator with Bundy.  They head do the long, posh 3rd floor hall, the Presidential Detail guarding the doors at the end.  But the familiar route fe strange, and lasting an eternity.  Kenny eyes the package under Bundy's arm, its TOP SECRET stamp visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Floyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. O'Donnell.  Mr. Bundy. The Agent opens the door.  Bundy pauses, Kenny with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuba. Bundy is tense.  But Kenny relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just Cuba?  Okay, I got work to do, see you guys downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny's office is a raging beehive of activity.  Kenny wo the phone as ASSISTANTS come and go with files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone, scary calm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, you worthless piece of disloyal shit.  You will pull Daly's man on the circuit.  You owe your goddamn job to this administration. (beat, listening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a word you need to learn.  It is the only word in politics.  Loyalty.  LOYALTY you motherfucking piece of shit! As Kenny THROWS the phone down at the receiver, and the PRIVATE DOOR to the Oval Office suddenly opens.  Kenny glances up.  President Kennedy stands there in the doorwa Kenny thinks he's reacting to the tirade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you looking at?  This isn't the blessed order of St. Mary the Meek. Kenny stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse us. The Assistants leave, shutting the door after them.  Kenn rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should come in here. Kenny starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still think Cuba isn't important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as far as the election goes. The President lets Kenny by into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE ENTER from a different angle than we usually enter in movies: through the side door.  The President's ornate de sits on the right, windows looking out on the Rose Garden behind it.  Kenny's gaze swivels to: THE OTHER END OF THE ROOM where the Interpreters, their crewcut chief, ARTHUR LUNDAHL, 50's, and Bundy stare at h They're surrounded by PRESENTATION BOARDS propped up arou the fireplace.  The President's rocking chair and sofas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to look down a bomb sight for a living, Ken.  What do you see? In eerie silence, as all eyes follow him, Kenny makes his among the presentation boards with the U-2 imagery, stops front of the picture of the six canvas-covered objects. unleashes a wave of memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hit a Nazi buzz bomb field in '45.  (beat, incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like a rocket base... He puts his hand out to touch the image, then turns and l to the President, knowing what they must be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Sunday morning, one of our U-2s took these pictures.  The Soviets are putting medium range ballistic missiles into Cuba. Shock.  Silence.  Kenny glances to the other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They appear to be the SS-4: range of a thousand miles, three-megaton nuclear warhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ in Heaven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bank of WHITE HOUSE OPERATORS work the switchboard, fin flying, voices overlapping in a babble of:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please hold for the White House...Mr. O'Donnell for Secretary McNamara... White House Operator... please hold...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny carries the phone with him as he paces hard from hi desk to his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principals are assembling in an hour.  See you then. Kenny hangs up.  The President enters.  A beat.  And in t beat, there's a void.  The two men are off their emotiona stride, trying to grope their way out of shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Bobby? Kenny nods, acknowledging the feeling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should be here any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. And we glimpse the chemistry of these guys by Bobby's absence.  It's like they're missing their third wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell are you? The President and Kenny hear him out in the hall.  And th tension goes out of them instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here! They turn to the door as BOBBY KENNEDY, 37, the President younger brother/Attorney General, enters.  Bobby shuts th door behind him, falls into Kenny's chair, and clearly grappling with his own disbelief, is hushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, guys.  What the hell's Khruschev thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have any indication of this from Georgi?  Any possible warning or sense of motivation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete snowjob.  And then we went out and told the country they weren't putting missiles into Cuba. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, you realize we just lost the midterms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gives a shit about the midterms now?  The Soviets are putting nuclear weapons ninety miles away from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean there's something more important than votes?  Didn't think I'd live to see the day, Ken. The President paces away, grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.  I feel like we've caught the Jap carriers steaming for Pearl Harbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President strides down the plush hallway, Bobby and K flanking him.  Unconsciously, all three men assume the sa gait: confident, powerful, no longer disoriented. And before our eyes, the three men's game faces appear, a they become the hard-ass leaders of the United States.  Secret Service Agents throw open the massive double doors the Cabinet Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they enter.  The group of men at the long, ornate Roosevelt-era table, rise as one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen. And the doors close on the eighteen men of EXCOM: The Executive Committee of the National Security Council.  Th are the legendary "Best and Brightest." The President makes his way down the line: shakes hands w Secretary of State DEAN RUSK, 53, distinguished, with a s Georgian accent, a distant reserve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean, good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President. The President leans past him, grasps the hand of the Secretary of Defense ROBERT MCNAMARA, 46, a gifted manage genius... the price of which is a cold, hard personality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob.  Bet you had a late night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep is for the weak, Mr. President. OFF TO THE SIDE, Kenny greets Vice President LYNDON JOHNS 54, and ADLAI STEVENSON, 62, Representative to the U.N., intellectual, well-spoken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyndon.  Adlai. The silver-haired war hero and politically savvy Chairman The Joint Chiefs of Staff, GENERAL MAXWELL TAYLOR, 50s, shakes the President's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCone's been notified and is coming back from the West coast.  Carter's here, though. He gestures to GENERAL MARSHALL CARTER, Deputy Chief of Operations for the CIA.  Carter nods to the President. THE CAMERA PANS OVER THE OTHERS. DOUGLAS DILLON, ex-banker, Secretary of the Treasury. ROSWELL GILPATRIC, studious Deputy Secretary of Defense. PAUL NITZE, 55, the detail-driven facts man, Assistant Secretary of Defense. GEORGE BALL, 50s, Undersecretary of State.  Eloquent, a m of conscience. U. ALEXIS JOHNSON, Deputy Under Secretary of State. EDWARD MARTIN, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America. LLEWELLYN THOMPSON, laid back, rumpled Soviet Affairs Advisor. DON WILSON, Deputy Director of the USIA. The President sits down at the center of the table, Rusk McNamara to either side, and the others resume their seat Bobby takes one of the over-stuffed chairs at the table. Kenny finds one along the wall behind the President, unde the windows to the Rose Garden to TED SORENSEN, 30s, the President's legal counsel and speech writer.  They greet other coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny. The room falls silent.  The President looks across the ta to GENERAL CARTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Let's have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Lundahl heads our photographic interpretation division at CIA.  I'll let him and his boys take you through what we've got.  Arthur? Lundahl, standing at the end of the room with briefing boards, steps forward with a pointer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, as most of you now know a U-2 over Cuba on Sunday morning took a series of disturbing photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sweltering Cuban countryside.  Shouting SOVIET ROCKET TROOPS, stripped to the waist, glistening with sweat, mac a clearing under scattered, limp palm trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our analysis at NPIC indicates the Soviet Union has followed its conventional weapons build-up in Cuba with the introduction of surface-to surface medium-range ballistic missiles, or MRBMs.  Our official estimate at this time is that this missile system is the SS-4 Sandal.  We do not believe these missiles are as yet operational. A bulldozer TEARS through the undergrowth.  FILLING THE SCREEN.  A 70-foot long MISSILE TRANSPORTER creeps along the bulldozer's wake like a vast hearse with its shrouded cargo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lundahl raps his second board: a map of the United States Cuba visible in the lower corner.  An ARC is drawn clearl across the U.S., encompassing the entire Southeast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRONBARK reports the SS-4 can deliver a 3-megaton nuclear weapon 1000 miles.  So far we have identified 32 missiles served by around 3400 men, undoubtedly all Soviet personnel.  Our cities and military installations in the Southeast, as far north as Washington, are in range of these weapons, and in the event of a launch, would only have five minutes of warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes, gentlemen.  Five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In those five minutes they could kill 80 million Americans and destroy a significant number of our bomber bases, degrading our retaliatory options.  The Joint Chiefs' consensus is that this is a massively destabilizing move, upsetting the nuclear balance. The President stares at Lundahl, and beating out each wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur.  Are. You. Sure? Lundahl looks around the room.  Everyone is hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. President.  These are nuclear missiles. The men come to grips with their own fears, own anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long until they're operational?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Taylor can answer that question better than I can. General Taylor drops a memo on the table WHICH BECOMES:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCHEMATICS slapped down on a camp table.  A group of Sovi site ENGINEERS point and gesture as they study their grou from a shaded hillock.  CLEARING CREWS and SURVEYORS work sweat in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GMAIC estimates ten to fourteen days.  However, a crash program to ready the missiles could cut that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor sees the grim looks all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to stress that there may be more missiles that we don't know about.  We need more U-2 coverage. Kenny lets out his breath.  He catches Bobby's eye.  This unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any indication - anything at all - that suggests they intend to use these missiles in some sort of first strike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at present, sir.  But I think the prudent answer is we don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have any sort of intelligence from CIA on what Khruschev is thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. President.  We don't.  We just don't know what's happening inside the Kremlin at that level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lied to us.  Two weeks ago Dobrynin told me to my face Khurschev had no intention of putting missiles into Cuba.  They said themselves, this is our backyard. There's angry agreement.  The President cuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I want first reactions.  Assuming for a moment Khruschev has not gone off the deep end and intends to start World War Three, what are we looking at? Rusk glances to his team at the end of the table.  Ball, Johnson, Martin, Thompson and Stevenson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I believe my team is in agreement.  If we permit the introduction of nuclear missiles to a Soviet satellite nation in our hemisphere, the diplomatic consequences will be too terrible to contemplate.  The Russians are trying to show the world they can do whatever they want, wherever they want, and we're powerless to stop them.  If they succeed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be Munich all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appeasement only makes the aggressor more aggressive.  Confidence in our security commitments around the world will falter, allies will become unsure in the face of Soviet pressure, and the Soviets will be emboldened to push us even harder.  We must remove the missiles one way or another.  It seems to me the options are either to build up the crisis 'til they give in, or we hit them.  An air strike. There's silence at the table.  Some nods.  Understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've worked up several military scenarios.  Before I ask General Taylor to lead us through the various options, I'd like for us to adopt a rule.  If we are going to strike, we must agree now that we will do it before the missiles become operational.  Because once they are, I don't think we can guarantee getting them all before at least some are launched. And there it is.  The clock is running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.  We need to consider... if we decide to act, there's a good chance we'll end up in a general war. The room falls silent.  The President leans back in his chair, studying the circle of men around the table, weigh them. Kenny and the others watch him in silence.  A long, drama pause.  A course that will change history is about to be chosen.  The President leans forward, folds his hands on table.  Fated.  Grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's clear we cannot permit Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba.  We must get those missiles out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and Bobby follow the President down a path through Rose Garden.  The shock of the morning has worn off.  The President stops, looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's going to matter what Khruschev's intentions are.  I tell you, right now... I don't see any way around hitting them. A long moment of silence as they move along again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we hit 'em, kill a lot of Russians, they'll move against Berlin.  They attack Berlin, that's NATO... and we're at war. The guys stop again.  The autumn day is bright, warm, ali The air, the distant city sounds derail the relentless tr of logic for a beat.  And in their faces we see that all three men, for the first time, feel the enormity of war, shadow over everything.  It's only a couple of steps away Steps that they're seriously contemplating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned if we do, but if we don't, we're in a war for sure somewhere else in six months. Pained, the President turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No choice.  This is going to cost lives any way we go.  Do nothing, and it could be 80 million  of ours.  We have to get rid of those missiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There've got to be alternatives to just going out and bombing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, Jack.  Taylor is saying we may have some time.  We've got to use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if there are alternatives that make sense - and I'm not saying there are - we need 'em.  Need 'em fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the allies?  Congress?  I think we may need to start letting key people know.  And they're all scattered across the country for the campaign.  We're going to need to get the U.N. staff in and warmed up.  Jesus... I don't even know if we've got secure communications with half our embassies since that the Soviets got that cryptographer of ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't worry about everything right now.  We've got to figure out what we're going to do before we worry about how we do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other thing is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I know.  CIA and the military fucked us on the Bay of Pigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to be pressing for a military solution soon.  We can't afford to let them ram their agenda down our throats.  We need to come with options other than air strikes so we have some sort of choice here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a bunch of smart guys.  We lock 'em up together in there, kick 'em in the ass til they come up with options. Kenny and the President look at him.  Bobby nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the President)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too politicized with you in there, anyway.  They need to be able to stick their necks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be the principals, a couple of the key guys from each department: the Executive Committee of the National Security Council.  We'll call it EXCOM. Kenny snorts a laugh.  Bobby shoots him a cross look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM.  Has a ring to it.  Like F-Troop. The President stops.  Bobby and Kenny stop, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Kenny and I only show for the meetings you call us into.  Impress us.  And do it fast. (to Kenny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in charge of keeping this quiet.  If word gets out before we know what we're going to do, there'll be panic.  And it'll ruin any chance of surprise if we decide to hit them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we need to do a few things right away.  No Pierre.  He knows, the press knows.  You're going to have to keep up your schedule - your movements are followed too closely.  And we need to get these guys out of the White House.  George Ball's got a conference room at State. (to Bobby)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reconvene over there this afternoon, come back here tonight. Bobby nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should bring in Dean Acheson.  He was fighting Soviets while we were still working the wards in Boston. The President nods his approval.  Looks at Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find him, Kenny.  We're going to need all the help we can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny moves hard and fast through the twisting warren of hallways and tiny offices which is the West Wing.  Sudden Scotty Reston pops out of a doorway behind Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Kenny!  Who died? Kenny glances over his shoulder at Scotty who points to a window.  A beat, then Kenny returns to look out the windo Outside, the West Wing Drive is FILLED WITH LIMOUSINES. A flash of dismay, but Kenny covers fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way it's going, the Democratic Party.  DNC strategy session.  If you can call it that. Scotty chuckles.  Kenny moves off, leading him away.  Ken assistant runs up behind him, holding out a slip of paper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? Kenny tries to look him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Tuesday.  You said to call.  When do I get my 45 minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what.  We're in Connecticut tomorrow for Ribicoff.  I'll get you up front with him during the flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. Kenny turns, harsh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? The Assistant eyes Scotty, holds his tongue.  Kenny takes slips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number you asked for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask for a lot of 'em.  Whose is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean Acheson's, sir. That shuts Kenny up.  Reston eyes the slip, then looks to Kenny's face.  And he knows something isn't right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go, Scotty.  See you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car jolts to a stop.  The CAMERA PANS up over the saggi suspension, the government plates, the hood ornament revealing half of EXCOM inside.  Kenny stands nearby wait for them. The doors open, and out they pile like a bunch of clowns: Bobby, McNamara, Rusk, Ball, Martin, Dioptric, Sorensen, Stevenson, and Nitze.  They're sitting in each others' la banging their heads on the roof, joking, but tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw secrecy.  You try having that fat ass sit on your lap all the way from Foggy Bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were excited.  I say no more. The gang falls in behind Kenny, trails him out of the gar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steel door unlocks, swings open, and Kenny marches at t head of the wedge of men into a long tunnel.  It's the infamous old passage from the Treasury to the White House Kenny and Bobby get a little ahead of the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody agrees the diplomatic route is out.  It's too slow, and they'll have the missiles finished. Kenny looks at him.  Then there's only one alternative. CAMERA wipes through the ceiling to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUND LEVEL.  Where the brilliantly-lit flag flutters ov the spotlit White House: their destination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GENERAL WALTER 'CAM' SWEENEY, head of Tactical Air Comman stands at the head of the table with a presentation board The men of EXCOM gather around Sweeney in their rumpled shirts, nursing coffee and cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have 850 planes assembling at Homestead, Eglin, Opa Locka, MacDill, Patrick, Pensacola and Key West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An F-100 Super Sabre stands under lights on a taxiway.  T CAMERA DESCENDS FROM ITS OVERHEAD SHOT, discovering the aircraft's sleek cockpit, menacing tiger-jaw paint job, t four 20mm cannons on its nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Due to the tropical foliage, the OPLAN calls for high-explosive and napalm loadouts for our ground attack sorties.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: The FLIGHT LINE where a full strike wing stands beyond th plane, pylons laden with weapons, GROUND CREW servicing t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other EXCOM members draw near the board, its order of bat strike maps.  They're grim, but fascinated.  Empowering.  Intoxicating.  Sexy.  Kenny sees it in the faces, even th President's.  Adlai does too, is upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still think there are diplomatic approaches we haven't considered yet. Kenny looks at Adlai.  The others around the room, embarrassed, don't respond.  The group has moved on and Stevenson hasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have high confidence in the expanded air strike option. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem, Mr. President, is that it's a short-term solution.  Khruschev can send more missiles next month.  The Chiefs and I believe we should follow up the air strikes with the full version of OPLAN 316.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An invasion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  We can be sure we get all the missiles, and we remove Castro so this can never happen again. Kenny looks around the room at the men, the murmurs of general agreement, senses the consensus building and is agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the Chiefs' recommendation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  Our best option is to commence the strikes before the missiles are operational.  The invasion happens eight days later. The President leans back in his chair, turns to the man a the far end of the table: DEAN ACHESON, 60s, former Secre of State.  He sits silent, like some revered oracle, the architect of the American Cold War strategy of containmen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean.  What do you think? Acheson arches an eyebrow, and when he speaks, his voice resonates throughout the room, powerful, smooth, hypnotic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, you have rightly dismissed the diplomatic option.  The Soviet will only tie you down in negotiation, and leave us short of our goal, the removal of the missiles.  Negotiating will do nothing more than give them time to make the missiles operational, complicating the necessary military task we have at hand. Everyone in the room listens to him with rapt attention, presence overshadowing the room, oracular:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the last fifteen years, I have fought here at this table along side your predecessors in the struggle against the Soviet.  Gentlemen, I do not wish to seem melodramatic, but I do wish to impress upon you one observation with all conceivable sincerity.  A lesson I have learned with bitter tears and great sacrifice. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soviet understands only one language: action.  It respects only one word: force. Kenny stares at the old man.  Acheson's gaze finds his through the cigarette smoke.  Acheson's eyes travel to th President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I concur with General Taylor.  I recommend, sir, air strikes followed by invasion, perhaps preceded by an ultimatum to dismantle the missiles if military necessity permits. Taylor nods, vindicated.  The others murmur their approva Bobby, at the table in front of Kenny and to his left, tr a dire look with Kenny.  This is happening too fast.  Bob holds his head, looks about at the others, deeply distres The President sinks back in his chair, staring at Acheson

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it appears we have three options.  Number one.  A surgical air strike against the missiles themselves.  Two, a larger air strike against their air defenses along with the missiles. Kenny eyes Bobby.  Bobby is writing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And three, invasion. Bobby looks over his shoulder at Kenny, and REACHES BACK him with a folded NOTE.  Kenny takes it, opens it. It reads NOW I KNOW WHO TOJO FELT PLANNING PEARL HARBOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're certainly going to do number one; we're going to take out these missiles, so it seems to me we don't have to wait very long.  We ought to at least be making those preparations. Kenny gives Bobby a curt nod.  Bobby tilts his head at th President: pass the note on to him.  Kenny rises, slips t note in front of the President. The President unfolds the note, and we HOLD ON IT and his reaction as in the b.g., out of focus, Taylor speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, we're preparing to implement all three options, though I must stress again, sir, there are risks to the strikes without the follow-on invasion. Bundy clears his throat.  Speaks from somewhere down the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to be clear, Mr. President, that we have definitely decided against a political track. The President folds the note away, glances at Bobby.  A b the President looks from Bobby to Acheson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean, how does this play out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your first step, sir, will be to demand that the Soviet withdraw the missiles within 12 to 24 hours.  They will refuse.  When they do, you will order the strikes, followed by the invasion.  They will resist, but will be overrun.  They will retaliate against a target somewhere else in the world, most likely Berlin.  We will honor our treaty commitments and resist them there, defeating them per our plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those plans call for the use of nuclear weapons. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is the next step? Acheson sits back in his chair, smooths his moustache.  A dramatic beat, and then his ominous pronouncement rings o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopefully cooler heads will prevail before we reach the next step. A chill runs down Kenny's spine.  He looks in shock to th President.  The President remains calm.  But in place of fated look the President has had, there's a hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acheson strides down the hall, Taylor, Sweeney, Carter an Bundy swept along behind him.  Bundy is on the defensive, others grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If McNamara'd get off the fence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, it's obvious.  It's the only option.  That asshole, Stevenson.  We can't let this drag out or we lose our shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bombing them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that the Kennedys' father was one of the architects of Munich.  The General is right.  There is only one responsible choice here. Bundy just nods.  Taylor grabs a door ahead for Acheson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's pray appeasement doesn't run in families.  I fear weakness does. And the men head into a stairwell going down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grimacing in pain.  He opens a pill bottle, takes two pil out.  He takes a whiskey in a shot glass from Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Kenny finishes pouring him and Bobby a couple of more sho discreetly turning a blind eye to the President's pain. The President returns from his desk, shirt untucked, disheveled, back stiff.  He eases into his rocking chair. Bobby lies sprawled on the couch.  Kenny sits down.  They look at each other.  A beat, something like shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ Almighty... They burst out laughing.  An absurd, tension draining mom They shoot their drinks, Kenny refills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Irish, but I don't believe in cooler heads prevailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acheson's scenario is unacceptable.  And he has more experience than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no expert on this subject, no wise old man. The President stares Kenny in the face, understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, Acheson's right.  Talk alone won't accomplish anything. Kenny considers the President, his face straight as he sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's bomb the shit out of them. Everyone wants to, even you, even me. (there's a point)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure would feel good. The President sees what Kenny's saying: it'd be an emotio response, not necessarily the intelligent one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I'm as conniving as they come, but a sneak attack is just wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right.  And things are happening too fast.  It smells like the Bay of Pigs all over again. Bobby picks up some reconnaissance photos on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if dealing with the Russians wasn't hard enough, we gotta worry about our own house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, listening to Taylor and Acheson, I kept seeing Burke and Dulles telling me all I had to do was sign on the dotted line.  The invasion would succeed.  Castro would be gone.  Just like that.  Easy. The President is rendered mute by a wave of pain.  Kenny Bobby aver their eyes.  When it passes, the President is hushed, grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something...immoral about abandoning your own judgement. Kenny nods, moved.  The President reaches out for the reconnaissance photos Bobby's flipping through.  Bobby ha them to him.  The President looks them over.  And when he speaks, there's humility.  And resolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't let things get ahead of themselves.  We've got to control what happens.  We're going to do what we have to make this come out right.  EXCOM is our first weapon. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll resort to others as we need 'em.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: A LONG SHOT of an ENORMOUS CROWD thronging a bunting-trim platform.  The President, barely recognizable at the distance, and a cluster of political VIPS wave from it, smiling. Kenny steps INTO FRAME, back here at the fringes of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't anybody in Connecticut have to work today? The crowd goes nuts.  Kenny paces, checks his watch, impatient to be done with the necessary diversion.  Kenny gazes off to his right and spots Scotty Reston, along wit half the White House press corps suckered along.  Scotty catches Kenny's look. Kenny turns away, but Scotty comes weaving over.  The President continues on, but all we hear is Scotty and Ken

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny!  What happened?  They didn't let me up front, said the President was on the phone the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Who was he talking to?  Acheson?  Come on, O'Donnell, everyone's wondering what's going on.  What's Acheson doing in town?  And don't give me some bullshit about DNC think tanks.  Acheson's Mr. Cold War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask him yourself?  You can have him on the way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving you a chance here: talk to me.  You can influence how this thing unfolds. But Kenny stands there, mute.  Reston just shakes his hea knowing for sure something's up.  He turns and heads back the press corps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and the President climb the stairs to the President plane, the crowd cheering him.  He gives a final wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheer up, you've neutralized the entire White House Press Corps for a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM meets in George Ball's small conference room at the State Department.  Bobby, in shirtsleeves, paces at the h of the table, very, very alone.  All eyes are on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No.  No.  There is more than one option here.  If one isn't occurring to us, it's because we haven't thought hard enough. McNamara squirms.  The others react in frustration.  CIA chief JOHN MCCONE, sharp, tough, conservative, is harsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes there is only one right choice, and you thank God when it's clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about a sneak attack!  How'll that make us look?  Big country blasting a little one into the stone age.  We'll be real favorites around the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, that's naive.  This is the real world, you know that better than anybody.  Your argument is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't so ethically particular when we were talking about options for removing Castro over at CIA. And there's nothing Bobby can say to that.  He props hims up on the table, stares at it as if there's an answer in shiny surface somewhere.  There is only the reflection of own face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't let my brother go down in History like a villain, like a Tojo, ordering another Pearl Harbor. McCone, Acheson, and Taylor share a look.  The last resistance to airstrikes is crumbling.  Finally, Bobby lo up at McNamara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob.  If we go ahead with these air strikes... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's got to be something else.  Give it to me.  I don't care how crazy, inadequate or stupid it sounds.   (beat, pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me. McNamara suffers under the gaze of everyone at the table, weighing the situation out.  And finally he ventures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months ago we gamed out a scenario.  It's slow.  It doesn't get rid of the missiles.  There are a lot of drawbacks. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scenario was for a blockade of Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny enters the office from his side door in the middle debate.  Military uniforms dominate the room: General Tay General Sweeney, and a host of briefing officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The situation is worse than we thought.  We count 40 missiles now, longer range IRBMs.  They can hit every city in the continental U.S. The President stares out the window at the Rose Garden, h back to Air Force Chief of Staff GENERAL CURTIS LEMAY, 60 Beetle-browed, arrogant, the archetypal Cold War general. Yet there is something about him, his intelligence perhap that suggests he's playing a role he knows and believes i The only other civilians in the room are Bobby, Bundy and McNamara.  The pressure from the military is almost physi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, as of this moment my planes are ready to carry out the air strikes.  All you have to do is give me the word, sir, and my boys will get those Red bastards. The President continues staring out the window.  Kenny ea over to the desk, leans on it, arms folded, interposing himself between the President and the soldiers.  Bobby jo him, side-by-side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long until the army is ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've just begun the mobilization under cover of a pre-arranged exercise, sir.  We're looking at another week and a half, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can begin the strikes, now.  The plans call for an eight-day air campaign.  It'd light a fire under the army's ass to get in place. That makes the President turn around, stare at LeMay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General LeMay, do you truly believe that's our best course of action?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I believe it is the only course of action.  American is in danger.  Those missiles are a threat to our bomber bases and the safety of our nuclear deterrent.  Without our deterrent, there's nothing to keep the enemy from choosing general nuclear war.  It's our duty, our responsibility to the American people to take out those missiles and return stability to the strategic situation.  The Big Red Dog is digging in our back yard, and we're justified in shooting him. Taylor steps in softly, smoothly: good cop to LeMay's bad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we have a rapidly closing window of opportunity where we can prevent those missiles from ever becoming operational.  The other options... He spares a look at McNamara, who watches the fireworks, folded, serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...do not guarantee the end result we can guarantee.  However, the more time that goes by, the less reliable the choice we can offer you becomes. The President, partially defused, looks from Taylor to McNamara.  LeMay steps forward, softer now, sincere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, the motto I chose for SAC is 'Peace is our Profession.'  God forbid we find ourselves in a nuclear exchange.  But if launched, those missiles in Cuba would kill a lot of Americans.  That's why I'm being such a pain in the ass about destroying them.  Destroying them immediately.  Hell, even Mac agrees. Bundy is uncomfortable.  Everyone turns to him.  He nods. Kenny realizes he's been co-opted by the military.  McNam does too, lets out a deep breath.  The President eyes Bun then paces out from behind his desk, walks up to LeMay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, what will the Soviets do when we attack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Kenny, Bobby and the President look at each other, unable believe what they just heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Because the only alternative open to them is one they can't choose. His pronouncement hangs there in the air: ominous, danger

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those aren't just missiles we'll be destroying.  We kill Soviet soldiers, and they will respond.  How would we respond if they killed ours?  No, they will do something, General, I promise you that.  And I believe it'll be Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMay walk out of the Oval Office with Taylor, Carter and their staffers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those goddamn Kennedys are going to destroy this country if we don't do something about this. There are dark looks on the faces of the other officers.  They agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the meeting next door disperses, the President rummage through Kenny's jacket which hangs on Kenny's chair.  Ken bemused, holds out the package of cigarettes the Presiden looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping LeMay pushed you.  I wouldn't mind going a few rounds with him. The President glances up, takes the proffered smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We knew it was coming.  I tell you, Kenny, these brass hats have one big advantage.  We do what they want us to, none of us will be alive to tell 'em they were wrong. Bobby, Rusk and Sorensen enter from the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, Gromyko should be on his way by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to go over what you're going to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's still no sign they know that we know about the missiles.  Been a lot of cloud cover; probably think we aren't getting any good product.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We keep 'em in the dark as long as we can.  But I sure as hell am going to test him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny comes out of the bathroom, and is buttonholed by th crewcut, bullet-headed Press Secretary, PIERRE SALINGER, the crowded, busy hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, I'm getting funny questions from the guys in the press office.  As Press Secretary, I need to know.  What's going on? Kenny wheels back into his office.  It's filled with peop But he bends confidentially to Pierre's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're planning to shave you bald next time you fall asleep on the bus. (off Pierre's get-serious look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Pierre, Gromyko just arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Press Corps throngs Kenny's tiny office, pushing and shoving for a vantage at the side door to the Oval Office waiting for the Gromyko photo-op.  Kenny stands shoulder- shoulder with Reston and Sorensen near the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they going to discuss the military exercises going on in Florida? Kenny doesn't even blink, but Sorensen does a poorer job hiding his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Scotty.  This meeting's been on the books for months.  It's just a friendly talk on U.S.-Soviet relations. Fortunately, the conversation is cut short as a dozen FLASHBULBS suddenly go off on a dozen cameras as the reporters crush in on the Oval Office, and Reston is swep forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: over the reporters.  The President, unsmiling, enters the room beside Soviet Foreign Minister, ANDREI GROMYKO.  Gro pauses for the photos: grim, dark haired, saturnine.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Kenny reacts.  At last, the face of the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA picks up the darkened windows: the meeting has gone long.  The CAMERA MOVES PAST Kenny and Sorensen stan in the doorway to Kenny's office, FINDS the President in chair across from Gromyko on the sofa.  Rusk, Ambassador ANATOLY DOBRINYN, and two INTERPRETERS around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that there should be no misunderstanding, the position of the United States, which has been made clear by the Attorney General to Ambassador Dobrynin here, I shall read a sentence from my own statement to the press dated September 13th. (beat, reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should missiles or offensive weapons be placed in Cuba, it would present the gravest threat to U.S. national security. The President stares at Gromyko as the translator finishe translating.  Gromyko sits there, enigmatic, cold, unreadable.  The translator finishes, and Gromyko stops h with a gesture so he can answer in his own accented Engli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, this will never be done.  You need not be concerned. The President hides his fury masterfully, and gazing over glasses, asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I do not misunderstand you: there are no offensive weapons in Cuba. A beat.  And Gromyko's response is flat, sure, steady:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. President.  We have sent defensive weapons only to Cuba. Kenny's blazing eyes could drill holes in the back of Gromyko's head.  His gaze swings to the PRESIDENT'S DESK. BENEATH THE DESK sit the BRIEFING BOARDS with the evidenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny emerges from his office.  The Soviet delegation disappears down the hallway with Rusk.  Kenny turns as Bo haggard, comes up from the other direction. Bobby gestures to the vanishing delegation, now being HARANGUED OC by the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? The President comes out of the next door down the hall, t Oval Office.  He turns and sees Kenny and Bobby.  He's li

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying bastard.  Lied to my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're split down the middle.  If I held a vote I think airstrike would beat blockade by a vote or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a consensus, Bobby.  Consensus.  Either air strike or blockade.  Something everyone'll stand by even if they don't like it.  I need it by Saturday.  Make it happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I can't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go into this split, the Russians will know it.  And they'll use it against us. The prospect disturbs the three men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you cancelled Chicago and the rest of the weekend yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't show for Chicago, everyone'll know there's something going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.  Cancel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. The President spins on him, unsure he heard correctly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not calling and cancelling on Daly.  You call and cancel on Daly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're scared to cancel on Daly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right I'm scared. The President pauses, looks at Bobby.  Bobby shakes his h don't look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll call, right?

dialogues.speaker: THEN SUPER
dialogues.text: Kenny threads his way through the host of SECRET SERVICE AGENTS and ADVANCE MAN cramming the hallway on the floor the hotel they've taken over.  From one of the rooms emer Salinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, all right.  What's going on here?  There's rumors going around an exercise in the southeast is related to Cuba.  I'm the Press Secretary.  I can't do my job if I don't know what's going on.  So what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you telling them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadly serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em you've looked into it, and all it is is an exercise.  And Pierre -- (beat, loaded)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President may have a cold tomorrow. Kenny stares at him, and the light dawns on Pierre.  Something big is going on and he's been cut out of it.  H stalks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, Kenny.  Goddamn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big 100-dollar-a-plate dinner is in full swing to a din band's tunes.  The President and Chicago MAYOR RICHARD DA make the rounds among the fund raising CROWD.  Kenny foll them at a respectful distance, greeting old cronies. Suddenly a MESSENGER hustles over to Kenny, hands him a n Kenny makes eye contact with the President, nods and leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny waits at the elevator.  Scotty saunters up behind h He sizes Kenny up, clears his throat.  Kenny turns around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are major rail disruptions in the South, two airborne divisions are on alert.  That exercise is an invasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know how Bobby has it in for the State of Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is about Cuba. Kenny freezes, then explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuba?  You're fucking crazy.  We are not invading Cuba.  Nobody gives a rat's ass about Cuba.  Not now, not ever.  If you print something like that, all you're going to do is inflame the situation.  Nobody talks to assholes who inflame situations.  Assholes like that can find themselves cut out of the loop. Reston is taken aback.  Stung silence for a beat.  Kenny' response is far louder than any "yes."  Now Kenny realize it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never threatened me before. And Kenny looks away, upset, but when he turns back to Reston, all that's there is his poker face.  The elevator arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  I'm not going to print anything until I have another source.  But I promise you, I'll get one. Kenny boards the elevator.  The doors shut on Scotty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny closes his eyes, sags against the wall, hating hims

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny enters his hotel room.  An Assistant waits with the phone, hands it straight to Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Assistant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Pierre I need to talk to him. (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM files past Bobby out of George Ball's conference ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring him back.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: The President emerges from the hotel, a HAT on his head. Press and a CROWD surge forward, crying out for the President's attention.  Kenny slides into the limo first the President waves to the crowd. Salinger waits on the sidewalk, and after the limo pulls away, the Press pushes in on him.  Pierre's face is pale he's just been told everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President has a cold.  He is cancelling the remainder of this trip and is returning to Washington on the advice of his doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White House Oval ROOM: opulent, filled with priceless and furniture, but cramped.  EXCOM members crowd around t center coffee table and the President.  Kenny stands behi him with Bobby.  Rusk rises from his seat, formal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, our deliberations have led us to the conclusion that, for the moment, a blockade of offensive weapons to Cuba is our best option.  But we'll still need a strong showing of support from the Organization of American States to give us an umbrella of legitimacy. At long last... Kenny looks at Bobby, relieved.  They've bought time to find a settlement.  Bobby smiles a small smile: what were you so worried about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blockade is technically an act of war, therefore we recommend calling the action a quarantine. McNamara folder in hand, opens it, SMASH CUTTING US TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOVIET FREIGHTER churning its way south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are between 20 and 30 Soviet ships underway to Cuba at this time. The CAMERA races along its side, discovering TARPULINED OBJECTS on deck, and on its stack, the RED HAMMER AND SIC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 800 miles out, the navy will stop them, board, and any vessels containing weapons will be turned back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Destroyer U.S.S. JOHN R. PIERCE putting out to sea, SAILORS racing over its deck, through hatches to its 5-in gun turrets.  The ship races by, AMERICAN FLAG streaming its stern distaff, FILLING THE SCREEN, WIPING TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President.  He listens, looks over the briefing paper McNamara continues.  Everyone watches the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quarantine prevents more missiles from reaching Cuba, but it doesn't remove the ones already there.  It gives the Soviets a chance to pull back without war.  If they refuse to remove the missiles before they're operational, we retain the option to strike or invade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We believe that a surprise attack would be counter to what the United States stands for.  We believe that an attack leaves us no room for maneuver, and the inevitable Soviet response will force us into a war we do not want.  A war that, this time, will really end all war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, there are still those of us who believe we should proceed with the strikes.  With the blockade, we lose strategic surprise and we run the risk of a first strike if the Soviets decide they have to use the missiles or lose them. The President gazes from one expectant face to another. he himself remains unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quarantine or air strike. Adlai clears his throat.  Everyone looks over at him.  He stares down at his clasped hands for a beat.  He's anguis about what he's going to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a third option.  With either course we undertake the risk of nuclear war.  It seems to me maybe one of us in here should be a coward. He smiles weakly, but gets no response from anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I guess I'll be.  Our third choice is to cut a deal.  We trade Guantanamo and our missiles in Turkey, get them to pull their missiles out.  We employ a back channel, attribute the idea to U Thant.  U Thant then raises it at the U.N. Adlai looks for support around the room, but meets only s gazes.  From McCone and General Taylor, contempt.  Dead silence for a long, long beat. Kenny's heart goes out to Stevenson as he watches the man commit political suicide.  Even Sorensen, standing behind him, unconsciously moves away.  At last the President spe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's possible, Adlai. (beat, to the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be asking the networks for air time Monday night.  I have not yet made my final decision.  We will announce our course of action then.  I want to thank you all for your advice, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, Bobby, and the President lean on the railing of th Truman Balcony, stare out at the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddman Stevenson.  Jesus.  Peace at any price.  You'd think nobody learned anything from World War Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody had to say it.  I respect Adlai for having the guts to risk looking like an appeaser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to pull him.  He's not going to be able to handle the Soviets in front of the U.N.  Zorin will eat him alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got bigger problems right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to try the blockades.  It probably won't work.  It may just be delaying the inevitable.  But we can't just go to war without trying not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I don't know. He stares out at the Ellipse where a little-league footba game sweeps across the grass, the shouts and screams of t CHILDREN, so alive, floating to them on the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded D.C. party spills out of Jim Rowe's house onto patio.  Kenny steps INTO FRAME.  He looks at the PARTYGOE the Washington social set.  He stands out, oppressed by t knowledge he's unable to share.  He takes a stiff drink. Suddenly out of the house totters Adlai, highball in hand Glassy-eyed, he grins at Kenny and joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just can't get away from you guys.  Escaping for a night on the town, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the town's most popular playboy, the President felt my presence would be sorely missed.  So in the interests of National Security... Kenny shrugs.  Adlai takes a long drink, closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta keep up appearances.  Of course, I don't care anymore.  I'm a political dead man.  You ever seen a man cut his own throat like I did today? Kenny has no answer to that.  He looks down, pained for Adlai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's all right. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to tell you, just talked to a friend.  Reston and Frankel have the story.  It's going to run tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, shut in the bedroom, paces on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to make it to Monday.  I'll try to lean on Reston, but you're going to have to call Orville Dryfoos.  This is the sort of decision the publisher makes himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York Times publisher ORVILLE DRYFOOS sits at his kitc table in his underwear, still half-asleep, phone to his e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I understand.  But we held on Bay of Pigs and it was the biggest mistake of my life.  What makes this any different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President, on the phone, stops pacing by his bedside table and exhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking you to hold the story until I can present our course of action on Monday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  But I need a reason to give my boys.  They're going to be screaming for my head on a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville.  I want you to tell them this: they'll be saving lives.  Maybe even including their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that, Dryfoos sits up.  Serious.  All resistance gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: AVE MARIA soars over the communion meditation at a crowde Sunday mass.  Kenny, in a pew, glances off to his left. The President sits nearby, head bowed.  But Kenny knows h not thinking about the mass.  And when the President at l lifts his head, Kenny sees the calm poise. The President has made up his mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby barges into Kenny's office.  Kenny, knowing his uni entry, doesn't bother to look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acheson called, DeGaulle's with us; haven't heard from anyone else yet. Kenny finally looks up.  Bobby's grim.  And an icicle for in Kenny's gut as Bobby relays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to talk to LeMay again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, Bobby, McNamara, Rusk, Bundy and half of EXCOM sta to the side of the room.  General Sweeney and LeMay stand front of the President's desk. The President, bowed in the window, is care-worn, a thous years old.  The shadow, the composition of the SHOT tells all.  It's down to what's in the heart of one man.  Kenny deeply moved at his friend's Gethsemane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cam, can you guarantee me you'll get all the missiles? Sweeney glances at LeMay.  LeMay's stern, frozen look wil him to say, very simply, "yes." But then the President turns around, looks Sweeney in the eye.  It would make Machiavelli himself tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I can guarantee we'll get all the missiles we know about. The President holds Sweeney in his gaze.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, we can get better than ninety percent of them. The President doesn't respond to LeMay's last-ditch appea Ninety-percent isn't good enough with nuclear weapons.  H moves to his desk, signs a paper, hands it to General Sweeney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As of seven o'clock Monday night, all United States armed forces world wide will stand up to DEFCON 3.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: A DEAFENING WHINE.  And INTO FRAME yawns the enormous spinning mouth of a B-52 bomber jet engine.  It closes on sucking us in like a maelstrom, but at the last second th

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA SLIPSTREAMS OVER IT --
dialogues.text: -- carrying us over the aircraft's wing.  The CAMERA pivo and the vast war machine crawls away underneath joining - -- a long LINE of identical behemoths, in single file inc down a taxi way which vanishes into the distance.  As the plane's immense vertical tail WIPES OUR VIEW:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA races toward a spotlighted concrete emplacemen over the immense BLAST DOOR which is sliding open, and DO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- into the depths of a missile silo.  The CAMERA speeds the side of the Titan missile, through CLOUDS of steaming liquid hydrogen, past FUELING HOSES which clamp one by on the rocket's side, past GANTRY ARMS pulling away.  The CA hurtles all the way to the bottom, SMASHING THROUGH THE F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark ocean, whitecaps whipping luminous around the aircraft carrier, U.S.S. ESSEX and her escorts.  Running lights flash red and green. The carrier's SIREN begins a lonely, eerie WOOP WOOP WOOP WOOP like some immense creature which has lost its mind. ship FILLS THE SCREEN, CUTTING US INTO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors to the Cabinet room.  A beat.  Then they SWING WIDE.  The President emerges, livid fury on his face, lea chaos behind: the Congressional briefing.  Kenny comes ou beat later, catches up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd worry that something was wrong if Congress offered you unconditional support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want this fucking job, they can have it.  It's no great joy to me. The President exhales, getting control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elected representatives of the people have spoken... (beat; determined)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's tell the people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny stands there in the doorway, arms folded.  As we PU AWAY FROM HIM, we REVEAL the three NETWORK T.V. CAMERAS staring straight at us.  Their red lights go on as one, a we swing around REVERSING TO: The President at his desk: telegenic, powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, my fellow citizens.  This Government, as promised, has maintained the closest surveillance of the Soviet military build-up on the island of Cuba...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first B-52 trundles to a stop at the end of the runwa It begins to throttle-up, the ROAR of its engine mounting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
