dialogues.text: ...unmistakable evidence has now established the fact that a series of missile sites is in preparation on that imprisoned island.  The purpose of these bases can be none other than to proved a nuclear strike capability against the Western Hemisphere... -- AND DROWNING OUT the President's speech as the plane lurches forward, down the runway into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Titan solo door GRINDS OPEN.  And the missile inside begins to rise into the white bath of the crossed spotlig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, in the defense of our own security and under the authority of the Constitution, I have directed that the following initial steps be taken.  First, to halt this offensive build-up, a strict quarantine --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President's words conjure the ESSEX battlegroup, its destroyers plunging through heavy seas, lit up in the nig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- on all offensive military equipment under shipment to Cuba is being initiated.  All ships of any kind bound for Cuba, if found to contain cargoes of offensive weapons, will be turned back.  Second: I have directed the continued and increased close surveillance of Cuba and its military build-up.  Should these offensive military preparations continue, further action will be justified --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flight of F-4 PHANTOMS drops INTO FRAME, lights flashin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I have directed the Armed Forces to prepare for any eventualities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  And the President looks up from his notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And third: it shall be the policy of this nation to regard any nuclear missile launched from Cuba against any nation in the Western Hemisphere as an attack by the Soviet Union on the United States, requiring a full retaliatory response upon the Soviet Union... The chilling words hang there in the air.  BLEEDING IN: t rising and falling WOOP WOOP WOOP WOOP which becomes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the voice of the Essex battlegroup: sparkling, alive, constellation of lights scattered across the sea.  One by the escort ships answer the carrier's SIREN with their ow wailing cries, an alien chorus among the ships, disappear and reappearing in the swells.  The communication crescen to its fever pitch -- -- and then the battlegroup goes to blackout.  Like a dyi universe, the answering sirens cut off, the life-lights w out, and an appalling darkness falls across the sea...

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: BLACKNESS, LIKE BEFORE A CURTAIN RISES.  And then a flickering: a FLUORESCENT LIGHT COMES ON.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Kenny, stripped to the waist, Sorensen and Bundy shave in nearby sinks.  Bobby barges in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're getting the Soviet response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Specks of shaving cream still on his face, Kenny paces, r the inky carbon as Bobby, Bundy and Sorensen read copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all rhetoric. (realizing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know how to respond yet. Kenny looks up.  The President enters from the Oval Offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now you're Khurschev.  What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, arms folded, stands behind the President, the rest EXCOM is looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- run the blockade.  They'll run the blockade. ADMIRAL GEORGE ANDERSON, 50s, dapper, the Chief of Naval Operations, nods from the far end of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is exactly what they appear to be preparing to do, Mr. President.  We're tracking 26 ships inbound to Cuba.  There's no sign they're changing course.  The closest ships, the Gagarin and the Kimovsk, will make the quarantine line by this time tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're concerned about the possibility of an incident with an innocent cargo carrier.  If it turns ugly, the Russians could use an ugly incident and bad world opinion as leverage to force us to remove the quarantine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or they could use it as an excuse to escalate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral Anderson, if the ships do not stop, what exactly are our rules of engagement? Anderson signals A BRIEFING OFFICER who hits the lights a an overhead projector which SMASH CUTS TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bridge of the U.S.S. John Pierce, a Gearing class destroyer.  A RADIO OPERATOR addresses a mike in Russian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russian-speakers have been transferred to all of our ships.  Once the quarantine takes effect in the morning, our ships will attempt to make radio contact with the approaching vessels.  They will be ordered to reduce speed and prepare for inspection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARINES in flak jackets grab M-16s off a rack, race by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ship's boat full of Marines lowers away, hits the water engine spraying as it launches forward - in dress rehears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An inspection party will then board and search the ship.  If weapons are found, the ship will be ordered to leave the quarantine area or be towed into port upon refusal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are on Admiral Anderson's overhead projections.  Bobby, restless, gets up, begins pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens if the ship doesn't stop for inspection or want to be towed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warning shot will be fired across its bow. Bobby stops, stares directly at the Admiral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happens if the ship ignores the warning shot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we fire at its rudder, disable it, and carry out the inspection. Kenny looks at the President who remains unmoved, unreada

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be no shooting without my explicit orders.  Is that understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The President glances at McNamara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Admiral, it looks like it's up to the Navy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Navy won't let you down, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, have we developed any more information on the missiles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are continuing to proceed with the development.  We're commencing low-level photography runs this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pictures will be used to firm up our estimates of the missiles' readiness and develop target packages for strikes should you order them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our guy running this show is the best.  Commander Bill Ecker of the Navy's VFP 62, the Fightin' Photo.  Something of a character, but the highest efficiency ratings we've ever had. He pushes Ecker's personnel file across the table, and as President opens it, on ECKER'S PHOTO, we SMASH CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man himself, COMMANDER BILL ECKER, 30s, playing cards smoking cigars with his wingman, LIEUTENANT BRUCE WILHEMY the PILOTS of VFP-62, the 'Fightin' Photo.'  They lounge, tinker with equipment.  Their ready room is filled with p ups, movie posters, and all things photographic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 millimeter, I'm listening.  On the big screen there's nothing like it. The other pilots heckle him, but are muted by Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To protect our pilots, we're prepared to retaliate against any SAM site or anti aircraft battery that opens fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out, Hollywood.  There's a new epic director in town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM listens in sober silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a flight of Thunderchiefs able to respond within minutes of an attack on our planes. Kenny catches the President's eye.  Kenny glances at the door.  Step outside, I need to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President and Kenny stand in front of the President's desk.  All the doors are shut.  Weak sunlight filters int the hushed room as if to a confessional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the morning I'm taking charge of the blockade from the situation room.  McNamara'll set up shop in the flag plot at the Pentagon, keep an eye on things there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  'Cause you get armed boarders climbing into Soviet ships, shots being fired across bows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about these low-level flights?  They're starting in what?  An hour?  Do you realize what you're letting yourself in for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need those flights.  We have to know when those missiles become operational, because when they do, we need to destroy them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.  But Castro's on alert and we're flying attack planes over their sites, on the deck.  There's no way for them to know they're carrying cameras, not bombs.  They're going to be shot at, plain and simple. Kenny's right, and the President looks away in frustratio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your political advisor, and I'm giving you political analysis here.  This is a setup.  The Chiefs want to go in.  It's the only way they can redeem themselves for the Bay of Pigs.  They have to go in, and they have to do it right.  It's that simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna protect those pilots. Thep President stares intently at Kenny.  Kenny glances a the door, his voice hushed.  He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're boxing us in with these rules of engagement.  If you agree to 'em, and one of our planes gets knocked down or one of the ships won't stop for inspection, the Chiefs will have us by the balls and will force us to start shooting.  They want a war, and they're arranging things to get one.  If you don't want one, we have to do something about it. The President understands.  He shakes his head, paces awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does a man get to a place where he can say, 'throw those lives away,' so easily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's harder for them to say it than they let on.  At the very least, they believe it's in our best interest.  And at the end of the day, they may end up being right. The President turns away, considers.  Then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triple check everything the Chiefs say to us with the guys who actually have to do it.  No one's to know about this but Bobby.  I need redundant control over what happens out there.  And if things aren't as advertised, you're going to make sure they come out the way I want them to come out, starting with this low level flight thing. Jesus Christ...Kenny is daunted.  For a beat he just star

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's going to be tough.  You know how these guys are about their chains of command...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any problems, you remind them those chains of commands end at one place.  Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and the President head for the Cabinet Room.  Rusk comes out before they get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President. The OAS meeting starts in an hour.  I haven't prepared at all.  We can't expect --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- we need this one, Dean.  The quarantine's legal if we get a mandate, otherwise it's an act of war in the eyes of the world.  Get me that vote.  Make it unanimous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, The Organization of American States hasn't had a unanimous vote since -- The President moves for the Cabinet Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- unanimous, Dean. Kenny slaps the dismayed Rusk on the back, heads off down hall away from the Cabinet Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny opens the door to the White House switchboard room. half-dozen OPERATORS work their lines, making connections the old-fashioned switchboard.  Unnoticed, he sizes them their skill.  They're all courteous, pretty, professional The CAMERA PANS down the line... and stops on a middle-ag matron at the end - the sternest, most scary of them all. Her name is MARGARET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White House Operator.  Yes sir. (beat, harsh, booming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaker McCormack, hold for the Vice President. Her voice is so severe, so smoker-gravelled, it makes the blood run cold.  This is the woman Kenny's looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, would you mind helping me out with a few special calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker, Wilhemy and their Pilots are in angry debate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orson Welles is a hack.  Now you want to talk about a director, you talk about David Lean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is a G-d.  Lean's the hack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, Bruce, nobody but Lean is making decent movies these days. (to Young Pilot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that fixed yet? Nearby, a YOUNG PILOT tinkers with a $300,000 spy camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhhh... yup.  Think so. Suddenly, the door opens and a pale DUTY SERGEANT enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir...telephone, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker enters, marches over to the phone.  All the SOLDIER the room stare at him.  Ecker wiggles his cigar to a corn of his mouth, picks up, styling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VFP-62, Fightin' Photo, here.  But what we really want to do is direct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret works her magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the White House Operator.  Hold for the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker blinks, becomes a mild lamb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, you don't know what shit is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, sitting on his desk, taps his fingers, looks at th phone.  He's kept Ecker on hold long enough - and picks u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, my name is Ken O'Donnell.  Special Assistant to the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker exhales.  It's not the President, but Ecker is so shaken up it might as well be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President has instructed me to pass along an order to you. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not to get shot down. Did he hear right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... we'll do our best, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand me correctly.  You are not to get shot down under any circumstances.  Whatever happens up there, you were not shot at.  Mechanical failures are fine; crashing into mountains, fine.  But you and your men are not to be shot at, fired at, launched upon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker sits down in a chair, sobered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, what's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny stands, drops the hard nose bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, if you are fired upon, the President will be forced to attack the sites that fire on you.  He doesn't want to have to do that.  It's very important that he doesn't, or things could go very badly out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker lets out a long breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I understand.  What about my men?  If it comes up hot and heavy, and we don't have anyone to protect us... I'm going to be writing letters to parents.  I hate writing letters to parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny nods to himself, feeling.  He's done it himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the President protects you, Commander, he may have to do it with the Bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker doesn't want to be avenged with atomic weapons.  No sane person would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've known the man for fifteen years.  The problem is, he will protect you.  So I'm asking: don't make him protect you.  Don't get shot at. Ecker down, deeply affected.  Suddenly, A BELL RINGS.  A TELETYPE goes off.  Ecker knows it's for him.  His orders

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. O'Donnell.  We'll do what we can. END INTERCUT. As Ecker hangs up, the Duty Officer rips off the ORDERS, hands them to Ecker, who takes one look, then gazes out t window at the runway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CART speeds down the flight line past the waiting F8U-1 Corsairs.  One by one, the four pilots accompanying Ecker Wilhemy jump off to mount their planes.  The cart still moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that fuel assayed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  It sucks.  Ain't for high performance babies like ours.  Shoulda brought some from home, but what can you do?  Last-second deployments... Wilhemy jumps off, then they're at Ecker's plane, and he jumps off.  Too late to worry about bad fuel now.  He hoi himself up and into the cockpit of the sleek navy jet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the canopy closes, Ecker powers up the engines, talks his flight over the Guard channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, time to play Spin the Bottle with our bearded buddy.  Nobody gets out ahead.  Remember, just sitting here we're only ten minutes from target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Crusaders swing around in pairs at one end of the run and then the first two throttle-up, flaps down, and drop their brakes.  The machines LUNGE forward like duelling d racers.  The FILL THE SCREEN, blow past.

dialogues.speaker: OVER KEY WEST
dialogues.text: The six Crusaders, in pairs, streak over the buildings an streets of Key West.  And in a heartbeat, cross the beach are out to sea. And already on the horizon, the low clouds and dark line land.  Cuba.  Ninety miles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ocean shrieks past so close you can see the white foa Ecker checks the altimeter: 150 FEET. A small fishing boat looms ahead, its net booms reaching like tree limbs.  The Crusader rockets over it. Ecker checks his instruments.  OUT THE WINDOW, the other Crusaders thunder over the water, past sailboats, cabin cruisers, the small-craft traffic outside Key West.  The speed sucks the breath away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to military throttle on my mark.  Three...two...one... mark. His airspeed indicator spins up to 400 knots.  And then h radio suddenly crackles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flameout flameout!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!  Me too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some altitude! Two of the Crusaders pull up, away from the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God damn.  Got it restarted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Yeah.  Me too.  Goddamn fuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I don't think she's gonna hold up for the run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Affirmative.  You two get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CRUSADERS
dialogues.text: The two planes with bad fuel pull wingovers to their left head for the airfield in the distance.  The four remainin planes streak over the ocean.  There are no more small cr this far out in the strait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuba, green and hazy, looms in the window.  Ecker throws series of switches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start your camera checks. A mechanical WHINE accompanies the switch-throwing.  Ecke pulls the trigger on his joystick and a THUMP THUMP THUMP hammers away.  There are green lights across his boards. One of the other pilots cuts in on the radio:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Failure.  All cameras.  Sonofabitch.  Film must not have fed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!  Shit!  Oh shit!  I just shot it all, boss.  Activator jammed open, its exposing everything now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright, Lenny, it happens to most men at some time -- Ecker grimaces, but his voice stays cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Scrub, you two.  Get out of here.  Still with me, Bruce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's affirm. The two Crusaders who've failed their camera checks break off.  And now Cuba's hills, the Havana sky line are right front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last two Crusaders streak over the surf, a white wake spray in their jetwash, and cross the beach with a boom.

dialogues.speaker: CRUSADERS
dialogues.text: The planes dip and rise with the green tropical contours, taking us on a sickening roller-coaster ride over Cuban countryside at treetop level. Palm forest, roads, can fields, more palm forest race by. And then, ahead, a large clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm 'em up.  We're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuban ANTI-AIRCRAFT GUNNERS shout as they traverse their guns in their sandbagged emplacement.  The low rippling thunder of the incoming jets becomes an earsplitting ROAR and the Crusaders blast out over the clearing.  The anti aircraft guns open up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilhemy jinks left to avoid a streaking of TRACER FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracers and flack pepper the air in front of Ecker's Crusader.  METAL PINGS, TINKS, RATTLES off the fuselage.  Anti-aircraft and small arms fire comes up from all over, hitting the planes multiple times.  He surveys the shapes the target zone dead ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights. And sees the long, canvas-covered objects on the ground. missiles.  They draw closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera. A steel fragment CRACKS his window, obscuring our view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action. And he thumbs the CAMERA SWITCH.  All twelve B-system cam begin banging away like cannons.

dialogues.speaker: CRUSADERS
dialogues.text: TRACERS lace the air between the two planes as they blast over the missile site.  Over trailers.  Over tents.  Over trucks.  Over trenches.  Over bulldozers. And then they're out over forest again.  It's all over in seconds.  The triple-A stops.  In unison, the two planes right, heading for the distant blue, blue sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny paces by the phone.  It rings.  He picks up, listen reacts.  Relief.  And we know the planes have made it bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker jumps down from the cockpit ladder and turns an eye his battered, pock-marked plane.  Wilhemy and the GROUND CHIEF come running up, the Chief letting out a whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit what daddy done brung home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoulda seen it, Chief, they --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- damn sparrows.  Must've been migrating.  Guess I hit a couple hundred. (to Wilhemy, stern)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many did you hit, Bruce? Wilhemy stands there, looking at Ecker, not sure what to of him.  The Crew Chief just starts laughing as more impressed GROUND CREW come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few.  I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was them 20 or 40 million sparrows? Ecker, sweat-plastered and foul, steps into the Chief's f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are bird strikes.  Sparrows to be precise.  Got a problem with that? The Chief stands there, glances at the plane one more tim and shakes his head, 'No.'  Ecker takes the Chief's maintenance clipboard from him, writes in big bold marker BIRD STRIKES.  He thrusts it back into the Chief's hands walks off; the astonished Wilhemy remains behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Kenny's credenza, a small black and white T.V. plays.  WALTER CRONKITE narrates on the television as a train lad with TANKS on flatbeds pulls out of a station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Massive military preparations are underway throughout the southeast in what Pentagon officials are confirming is the largest mobilization since Korea.  The railways have been nationalized to assist in the deployment, here transporting elements of the U.S. 1st Armored Division from Ft. Hood, Texas. A PHONE RINGS.  Kenny turns from the T.V., turns down Wal Cronkite, as he answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Ball stands at the back of a crowded room filled w applauding OAS DELEGATES.  It's for Rusk, at a podium up front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny.  The vote just came down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny opens his door, lets Rusk in.  The President, Bobby half of EXCOM look up.  Rusk stands there somber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unanimous.  One abstenation. And then he breaks into a huge grin.  Everyone cheers him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About time something went our way. An Assistant enters behind Kenny.  Kenny senses him, turn the others move to shake hands with Rusk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone, Mr. O'Donnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, grinning, ducks back into his office, closes the d after the Assistant leaves.  He picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecker stands at a phone, stares out a window at a replace plane being fueled.  A Crusader, not his shot-up one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Donnell, I've been ordered to deliver the film to the Pentagon personally.  What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny thinks fast.  Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chiefs must want to talk to you. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Commander, they'll want to know if you were fired on.  Were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could say that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander.  Do not, under any circumstances, tell the Chiefs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: E-RING.  Then SUPER: THE PENTAGON Ecker, still in his sweat-drenched flight suit approaches security checkpoint.  GUARDS secure his sidearm and user through a doorway.  A sign over it reads JCS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings open into the Joint Chiefs' SOUND-PROOFED briefing room known as THE TANK.  LeMay, Taylor and Ander sit there around the table.  Ecker salutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander William B. Ecker reporting as ordered! LeMay rises, prowls over to Ecker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son , I want to know just one thing.  Those bastards shoot so much as a BB gun at you? A long beat.  Sweat runs off Ecker's head.  He can smell LeMay's breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, it was a milk run, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny joins the President and General Taylor in the hallw as they head for the Oval Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It appears our low-level flights are getting back okay.  Some unconfirmed reports of small-arms fire from some of the missions, but that's it. Slightly behind them, Kenny looks sidelong at Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess we can't blame Khruschev for a few patriotic farmers.  And the ships?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still heading for Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Then I guess it's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASHBULBS go off all around the room as the President wa in, goes over to his desk.  Reporters observe silently, T cameras track him; Kenny, Bobby and Sorensen watch as the President sits, takes a pen form his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In accordance with this afternoon's vote at the OAS, the quarantine shall hereby be effective as of ten o'clock tomorrow morning. Kenny observes in silence as the President SIGNS the Proclamation of Interdiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Oval Office has emptied out.  Only Kenny, Bobby, Sore and the President remain.  The President looks out the window, Sorensen sits in a chair in front of the desk.  B and Kenny sit on the edge of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last summer I read a book.  The Guns of August.  I wish every man on that blockade line had read that book. The President moves over to the GLOBE by his desk, spins stopping in on Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: World War One.  Thirteen million killed all because the militaries of both alliances were so highly attuned to each other's movements and dispositions, afraid of letting the other guy have a theoretical advantage.  And your man in the field, his family at home, couldn't even tell you the reasons why their lives were being sacrificed. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why couldn't they stop it? Can we?  The President's fingers turn the globe.  It stop North America.  Kenny and Bobby listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here we are, fifty years later.  One of their ships resists the inspection.  We shoot out its rudder and board.  They shoot down our planes in response.  We bomb their anti-aircraft sites in response to that.  They attack Berlin.  We invade Cuba.  They fire their missiles.  We fire ours. The President sets the globe gently spinning and walks aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny rubs his eyes, listens to his phone and the WOMAN'S VOICE at the other end.  It's his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you going to be home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Helen.  I want you to keep the kids close tomorrow.  Leave the T.V. on, sleep with it on in the bedroom until I tell you you can turn it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Nothing you don't know about.  Tomorrow's the big day.  Just have the car ready to go if I call or if the Civil Defense Warning comes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens to you?  I'm not leaving without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be evacuated with the President. A long silence on the other end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  So while you're under a rock somewhere with the President, what am I supposed to do with your five children? And to that, there is no answer.  A beat, and it's all Ke can promise:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find you.  But we're not going to let it come to that.  I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny hands Bobby and Bundy cups of coffee.  The three me nurse them in the silence of the abandoned cafeteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen just asked me what sort of arrangements we have for the families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just checked myself. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're being issued identity cards.  Call comes, and evacuation officers meet them at pre-arranged departure areas.  They go by helicopter to Mount Weather.  We meet them there. Bobby looks at his coffee, then up at Kenny.  He gently shakes his head.  It's all a sham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course that's for morale.  The missiles only take five minutes to get here.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Kenny bolts upright from his couch.  He rubs his face, si on the edge in the dark for a beat.  He's not going back sleep.  He grabs his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny makes his way through the dim, deserted halls.  Somewhere in the distance a phone rings.  He reaches a do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, bundled in an overcoat, steps outside the North Entrance.  The cool air invigorates him.  He eyes the fen Pennsylvania Avenue beyond it, seeming to isolate this wo from the living city beyond.  He starts for the main gate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WHITE HOUSE POLICE OFFICER jumps up as Kenny approaches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like me to call a car, Mr. O'Donnell. Kenny checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will it take to get someone up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen minutes, maybe.  To your house, sir? Kenny considers, shakes his head.  He wants to go home, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No, I'll let her sleep.  Let 'em sleep. Kenny says it with a certain finality.  The Police Office nods, and Kenny wanders out through the gates, shoulderin the weight of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny makes his way down a sidewalk not far from the Whit House.  A 24-hour drug store's doors are open.  He pauses Inside, a knot of PEOPLE - late-night deliverymen, a cop, store employees - talk in undertones at the counter.  Beh it, a T.V. is signing off with the national anthem.  Sobe voices, sober looks.  Kenny moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cluster of COLLEGE STUDENTS talk at a news stand.  They waiting for the NEWSIE to cut the bands of the next day's Washington Post, the bundles just being thrown to the sidewalk from the delivery truck.  Kenny approaches. In their thing beards, counter-culture clothes, the kids so young, Kenny so old.  Kenny buys a newspaper, its dire headlines, every story about the crisis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, newspaper under his arm, continues down the street Up ahead, the lights are on in a Catholic Church.  Lines CHURCHGOERS are at the door.  Kenny stops, surprised at t sight this late.  And then he sees the hand-painted banne CONFESSIONS 24 HOURS.  PRAY FOR PEACE. Kenny is moved.  He glances over his shoulder, and then.. joins the line himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny's WATCH reads one minute til ten o'clock.  PULL BAC

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL
dialogues.text: Kenny, standing just inside the open doors to the White H Situation Room, a state-of-the-art conference room.  A lo central table surrounded by leather chairs with phones an screens built in.  T.V. monitors hang from the ceilings i the corners.  There are no windows, just oppressive bunke like walls.  It's far underground. Across the room the President paces, phone in hand.  Half EXCOM is in their seats.  The other half, along with a st stream of DUTY OFFICERS, are coming and going.  Kenny ste aside for a Duty Officer, listens to the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Bob, I'm putting you on intercom. Suddenly, McNamara's VOICE fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys, can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNamara stands, phone in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have one minute til ten here --

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMERA TRACKS AROUND HIM, REVEALING
dialogues.text: A large, elaborate war room, like Mission Control.  Big screens, plexiglass tracking boards, tiered banks of communications equipment.  A massive LIGHT TABLE on the f at the center of the room projects a map of the Caribbean Atlantic.  Arcing across it is a RED LINE: the blockade. The map is covered with cryptic military notations; WATCH OFFICERS on a platform which swings out over it update th latest ship positions. McNamara's in a booth overlooking the room.  It's open to next tier below where Admiral Anderson is giving orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and no sign of them stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and Bobby move to the President's end of the table, down across from each other in mirror-image fashion.  EXC looks to the President.  The second hand of the clock on wall wheels past 12.  A hush falls over the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, the quarantine is now in effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNamara is mute for a beat.  He turns to view the big ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it looks like our first customers are the Gagarin and Kimovsk. He nods to Admiral Anderson, who calls an order down to a Watch Officer on the floor, and on screens all around the room, a sector of the map MAGNIFIES the unfolding encount

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- between the destroyer, U.S.S. Pierce and the SOVIET FREIGHTERS Gagarin and Kimovsk.  The Pierce's bridge wing are crammed with helmeted OFFICERS and LOOKOUTS.  They pe through binoculars at the distant ships, plowing ahead, straight for them.  The CAPTAIN lowers his binoculars, determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helm, shape heading for intercept, zero one zero.  All ahead full --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- new contact!  New contact! Everyone whirls to the bridge.  The Captain steps forward

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain ducks into the CIC.  The CHIEF SONARAN report

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Submerged contact, designation Sierra one at 6000 yards bearing 030.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A submarine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President reacts.  Kenny and Bobby react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's protecting the freighters. Consternation.  The President picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, is there any way we can avoid stopping a submarine first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not, Mr. President.  The sub has positioned itself between the Pierce and the Soviet ships.  Admiral Anderson insists it's too much of a risk to proceed with stopping the freighters.  The Pierce would be a sitting duck for the sub. All around the room frustration.  Bobby shakes his head.  Kenny sinks back in his chair.  The President hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me through to the Pierce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral Anderson nods to a COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER.  The m makes the connection on a switchboard. McNamara casts an eye to the map.  The two red MARKERS labeled Gagarin and Kimovsk are joined by a third: the SU They are ALMOST TOUCHING the blockade line.  On the other side, the single blue marker for the Pierce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain enters the bridge, takes the phone from the a of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President holds the phone, agonized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, can you force that submarine to the surface for inspection without damaging it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can bring it up, Mr. President.  But whether it's damaged or not is up to the sub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President lowers the phone, looks to Bobby and Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if they force it up, that sub will be inspected over the crews' dead bodies.  They'd be executed for allowing it when they got home. All eyes are on the President.  His eyes are closed tight face gray, hand over his mouth.  The time of decision is hand.  He lifts the phone once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, force the sub to the surface for inspection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President!  We're receiving reports that the ships are stopping!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, belay that order! (to McNamara)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, where's that coming from!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will somebody find out what's going on?! McCone jumps up, leaves the room.  The President looks at Kenny, tense.  Everyone holds their breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they stopping? The HISS of static on the open line fills the room.  Sile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookouts peer across the water at the oncoming Soviet Freighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the Soviet Bridge, where their LOOKOUTS are staring ri back through their binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HISS of static.  And then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNamara is grinning wildly at the chaos unfolding in the flag plot below.  Phones are ringing everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LIGHT TABLE
dialogues.text: The Watch Officers' hands fly from one notation to the ot circling the Soviet ships, marking them DEAD IN THE WATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- we've got reports coming from all over!  The ships are stopping!  Some... are turning around!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room EXPLODES, victorious.  Kenny and Bobby break int big grins, grab each other.  Kenny pumps the President's hand.  Rusk and Bundy slap each other on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were eyeball to eyeball and I think the other fellow just blinked. The ruckus goes on for a minute.  McCone comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President. His voice is lost in the celebration.  McCone calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President! The hubub dies away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we have the tally from NSA.  We have twenty ships stopping and or turning around.  Six, however, appear to be continuing for the line.  Including the Gagarin and Kimovsk. The elation goes out of the room.  Kenny looks at the President.  The President picks up the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, have the ships you're observing changed course?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. President.  They've just crossed the quarantine line. Bobby grips the edge of the table, immediately believing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an accident.  They must not have gotten their orders yet.  Let 'em go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlikely, Mr. President.  We've been monitoring transmissions from both the Gagarin and Kimovsk.  Their radios are working fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One ship, an accident maybe.  Six: this is intentional. The President looks to Bobby.  He has no answer.  Kenny's mind races over the variables, and he leans forward, inte suddenly understanding in a flash of insight:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're right.  This is intentional. He glances around the room.  All of EXCOM is looking at h Bobby stares at Kenny, too shocked to feel betrayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khruschev's stopped the 20 ships which are carrying contraband, and he's letting the ones which aren't go through, hoping for an incident.  I think we should let them go. Bobby relaxes.  Around the table there are nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we do, it erodes the credibility of the quarantine.  He'll just send more through tomorrow. The President looks at Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we deal with it tomorrow.  But today he's stopped most of them.  He's done something smart here.  We gave him an ultimatum, and he's agreed to most of it, preserving just enough room to save face.  We need to do something just as smart now. Bobby's nodding, following the argument.  Kenny looks aro the room for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNamara, pacing on the phone, jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I agree.  Let them go.  Four of the six continuing ships are still a day away from the line.  They've stopped all the ones we suspect have weapons aboard.  It would look bad shooting up a freighter full of baby food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President holds Kenny's gaze, then lifts the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, I want you to maintain contact with those ships.  Do nothing until I order otherwise.  Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. President.  Contact only. He hangs up, turns to Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, Bobby and the President make their way across the lawn, out of earshot of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to speak when spoken to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it a rest.  You were thinking the same thing, just didn't have the guts to take the heat. Bobby likes getting under Kenny's skin.  Bobby aims a pun at his head which Kenny knocks away.  The President chang gear, serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can horsetrade with Khruschev on ships.  But it doesn't get us any closer to removing those missiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to hope it's a signal that he'll back down on the real issue too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to stop a ship eventually, show the quarantine's got teeth, or we'll prove McCone right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNamara's on his way back here now.  We need to pick the right ship.  No subs.  No armed boarding parties either.  We need a little more time to figure this one out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's move the quarantine line. It's a simple suggestion.  The President considers him a beat, and then McNamara emerges from the White House, hea for them.  The three friends assume their more reserved, political faces as he comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President.  Bobby.  Kenny.  The Essex battle group has the Gagarin, Kimovsk and the sub escort under their thumb.  We've got a few hours now before we need to worry about any more flashpoints on the line. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could use a few more hours.  I think we should consider moving the quarantine line back to 500 miles. Bobby and the President look at Kenny like he's some kind Svengali.  Kenny just stands there, poker faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and McNamara enter the White House from the South L They stride down the hall, side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving the line.  Stroke of genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snappish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is.  But the President needs to realize we're going to have to stop a ship eventually. They turn a corner, silence for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chiefs are looking for a provocation out there.  The President's going to come under enormous pressure.  You have to keep 'em on a short leash, Bob. McNamara spares Kenny a short, nasty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must think I'm blind and stupid.  I've already gotten the birds and bees from Bobby.  The President doesn't have to double-barrel me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, goddamn it.  We're talking about a possible nuclear war.  You dropped the ball on Bay of Pigs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you sonofabitch, goddamn it, I didn't drop --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in the room.  It was your purview.  It was your job to make sure Bissel wasn't fucking us over and you didn't do it.  You've got the most important job in the world right now.  You're the smartest guy the President has. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides me. That gets an amused snort from McNamara, breaking the tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody ever tell you you're an egomaniac and a prick, O'Donnell? Kenny stares him in the eye, serious, hushed.  A friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to be the best you've ever been. McNamara enters the elevator.  He turns, stands there fac Kenny for a dramatic beat.  Then the doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER CRONKITE, on the B&W T.V. screen, sits in fron map showing Cuba and the blockade line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- well, it appears the world has just received a reprieve.  Defense Secretary Robert McNamara has announced that the quarantine zone has been moved from 800 to 500 miles.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK, REVEALING
dialogues.text: Kenny watching the T.V., is yelling at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out how close our exercises are coming to their cruise missiles.  I'm calling you back in five, and you will have an answer for me or I will come down there and beat the shit out of you. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you can press charges, and I'll get a Presidential pardon. He hangs up, hears SHOUTING from the Oval Office.  He goe the door, enters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and sees the President leaning over his desk, jabbing finger at General Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- how the goddamn hell did this happen?  I'm going to have Power's head on a platter next to LeMay's! (noticing Kenny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Kenny, did you hear me give the order to go to DEFCON 2?  I remember giving the order to go to DEFCON 3, but I must be suffering from amnesia because I've just been informed our nuclear forces are DEFCON 2! Kenny realizes he's not joking as he spots Bobby sitting the couch behind Taylor, pale as a ghost.  Taylor, embatt wants to die, but stands there like a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nose cone of a TITAN MISSILE, its 20 megaton nuclear warhead wrapped in the steel re-entry shell.  Cold, silen fearsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, the orders were limited to our strategic forces in the continental U.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taylor continues on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technically, General LeMay is correct that SAC has the statutory authority -- The President punches his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I have the authority.  I am the commander-in-chief of the United States, and I say when we go to war!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not at war, sir, not until we're at DEFCON 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, the Joint Chiefs have just signalled our intent to escalate to the Soviets.  You have signalled an escalation which I had no wish to signal, and which I did not approve.   But Taylor knows this very well.  And the way he's suffer it's clear he's taking the heat for his underlings.  From over on the couch Bobby chimes in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMay... he's history. The President glances at Kenny who stands there, speechle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here, Max. The General leaves.  Kenny closes the door, wanders deepe into the office.  He looks from the President to Bobby.  There's a long, long beat of shocked silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rescind the order.  Can all the Chiefs.  Put Nitze, Gilpatric and the Undersecretaries in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't do that, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, we can't rescind DEFCON 2.  The Soviets will think we've gotten sweet on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we can't purge the Chiefs.  Our invasion talk will look like a bluff.  Or even that there's been an attempted coup. Bobby is disgusted, but knows they're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNamara won't be able to handle them.  It's too much for one man... (knowing look to Kenny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...with all due respect to our heroic fifth column. The President collapses in his rocking chair.  Kenny lean over the back of the sofa next to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got Khruschev's attention with the blockade.  If we want a political solution.  I think it's time to turn up the diplomatic heat.  Cause if we let this go on too long, we're going to find ourselves in a war. Bobby looks at the President, meaningful.  The President turns to Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been considering a variation on one of Stevenson's ideas.  We're going to send up a trial balloon through Lippman.  The Jupiter missiles.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: The West Wing looms behind Kenny and Bundy.  Kenny, poker faced, takes a drag on his cigarette.  Bundy nervously fl his, looks away from Kenny a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think of Lippman's column this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's a bad idea. Bundy turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.  Look, everyone is furious about it.  We trade away our missiles in Turkey and we're fucked politically. Kenny grinds his jaw, but doesn't say anything.  He agree Bundy steps up to him, confiding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta stop 'em.  We know it's Jack and Bobby's idea - they leaked it to Lippman.  The military guys are going ape, and they're not alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they should speak up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Ken, you know it's not that easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it isn't.  They don't trust the people that feel this way.  But these people are right.  And the Kennedys are wrong. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need you to tell 'em, Kenny.  They'll listen to you. Kenny prickles, intense, but Bundy presses on, too wrappe in his own thinking to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Bobby are good men.  But it takes a certain character, moral toughness to stand up to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You listen to me.  Nobody, nobody, talks about my friends that way.  You're fucking here right now because of the Kennedys.  They may be wrong.  They make mistakes.  But they're not weak.  The weak ones are these 'people' who can't speak their own minds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I don't mean they're weak. Kenny gets in his face, intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they just lack 'moral toughness.'  And you think I'll play your Judas.  You WASPS and blue-bloods never understood us, thinking we want into your club.  Well we got our own club now. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you guys don't realize fighting with each other is our way.  Nobody plays us off each other.  And nobody ever gets between us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny throws himself on a chair in the bedroom's sitting area, newspaper in hand.  The President, buttoning his sh in a full-length mirror, sees him.  There's a TV on.  The President selects a tie from a nearby rack, eyes the pape

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just a bunch of crap about withdrawing our Jupiter missiles in Turkey if the Soviets'll do the same in Cuba. The President's eyes flick over to him in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to listen to this again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we made a trade, we'd be giving in to extortion, and NATO would never trust us again.  We'll get clobbered in world opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a goddman trial balloon.  Trial is the operative word, here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then somebody'd better deny it publicly. The President turns around, heads over to the T.V.  Kenny folds his arms, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, O'Donnell, you're the one saying we need to move forward on a political solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a good political solution. ON THE T.V. Live coverage of the United Nations Security Council meetings.  Holding forth in Russian is VALERIAN ZORIN, 50 tough, likeable, the Soviet Ambassador to the U.N. and chairman of the Security Council.  A translator relays th meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call on the world to condemn the piratical actions of America...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: The President's jaw tightens.  He turns to Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to turn up the heat?  You call Adlai.  Tell him to stick it to Zorin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, phone to his ear, suffers as Bobby harangues him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai's too weak!  We have to convince Jack to pull him, get McCloy in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't take him out this late in the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zorin will eat him alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then talk to your brother, goddamn it.  The two of you don't need any advice to get into trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's gotten into you? Kenny throws the Lippman article at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, still sore about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something your father would've come up with. Silence.  Terrible silence.  That paralyzes Bobby.  Kenny stares at him.  He means it, but regrets it, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm just trying to make a point.  This idea is that fucking bad. But Bobby gets it.  Kenny shifts gears, lets it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai can handle Zorin.  He knows the inning and the score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He better.  Because nobody thinks he's up to this.  Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The U.S. suite is in frantic preparation, STAFFERS coming going.  Stevenson takes his phone from a SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny turns to gaze at his little T.V. in the credenza, U coverage continuing, as if he could see Adlai there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai, it's Kenny.  How're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai is packing up his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy, Ken. What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny rises from his chair, paces toward the T.V.  He pau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President told me to pass the word to you: stick it to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai looks around to his own T.V., showing the session g on downstairs.  Zorin, ON CAMERA, dominates the council: alternately bold, aggressive, and then reasonable.  Even Russian, with the lagging translation, he's formidable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny is watching exactly the same performance.  Zorin is masterful.  Kenny knows it.  And when he talks to Adlai, with the fatalism of a coach knowing he's putting his thi string quarterback in against the all-Pro linebacker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai.  The world has to know we're right.  If we're going to have a chance at a political solution, we need international pressure.  You got to be tough, Adlai.  You need to find it, old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai watches his Staffers leave his inner office.  He he Kenny, and everything Kenny is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you.  I'm glad it's you calling.  I thought it would be Bobby.  If they're still sticking to their stonewall strategy, I'll get 'em. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ken. Adlai lowers the phone to its cradle.  An ANXIOUS STAFFER sticks his head in the door, a concerned, questioning loo his face. Adlai adjusts his tie.  HIS HAND IS SHAKING.  He notices and manages a brave smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an old political cat, Jimmy. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've got one life left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai, briefcase in hand, marches down the hall at the ha of his team: Staffers and Photo Interpreters with large leather portfolio bags.  The big double doors to the coun chamber loom, and he gestures to the Photo Interpreters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here. And then a DOORMAN throws open the door for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai enters.  He is instantly dwarfed by the enormous ro Lights, T.V. cameras, the imposing circular arrangement o delegation tables.  And the entire world is watching. Adlai pauses.  Then as the first SECURITY COUNCIL MEMBERS begin to notice him, he heads for the vacant seats for th American delegation.  The ROMANIAN DELEGATE saws the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through translator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we call upon the world to condemn this purely American provocation... But as the Romanian wheezes on, all eyes are on Adlai.  A takes his seat, his Staffers behind him.  They pass him u papers, and he spreads them before him, taking no notice the entire room is staring at him. Adlai finally glances up.  Across the circle sits Zorin, the flesh, at the head of his own tough-looking DELEGATIO He acknowledges Adlai with a superior smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, the people of Romania, stand in solidarity with the people of Cuba and their revolution in the face of this American threat to world peace.  Thank you, Mr. Chairman. The Romanian Delegate leans back from his microphone.  Zo leans forward, begins in Russian, and the Translator's vo catches up with him.  His tone, body language, composure all that of complete confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through translator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are glad you could join us, Mr. Stevenson. Adlai nods, returns to his notes, as Zorin continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the last couple of hours I have heard nothing but questions from the world here.  The United States has led us to the brink of calamity.  The peoples of the world want to know why.  We are told again and again of this so called incontrovertible evidence of offensive weapons in Cuba.  Yet we are not allowed to see this evidence.  Are your spy planes so secret you cannot share this evidence with us?  Some planes?! The audience laughs.  Zorin basks in it.  And then grows stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or perhaps there is no such evidence.  Perhaps the United States is mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM watches the coverage on the situation room's T.V.'s The President and Bobby sit side by side, Kenny just behi them.  Bobby checks his watch, looks at the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make the call, and Adlai is out.  McCloy goes in. Bobby looks back at Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope it doesn't come to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zorin stares at Adlai.  Adlai studiously ignores him, wor on his own papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The United States has no facts in hand.  Falsity is what America has in its hands - false evidence. Zorin leans back in his chair.  Adlai finally looks up. meets Zorin's icy bravura.  He notes the cameras around t room.  This is the grandest stage of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chair recognizes the representative from the United States. And in that moment, Adlai becomes the spokesman for Ameri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let me say something to you, Mr. Ambassador, we do have the evidence.  We have it, and it is clear and incontrovertible. Adlai's tone is definitive.  A tremor of interest passes through the various delegations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And let me say something else.  Those weapons must be taken out of Cuba.  You, the Soviet Union, have created this new danger, not the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM is transfixed by the continuing debate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Adlai! They all crowd the T.V. as if it were a title fight.  Exc for Bobby.  Kenny glances over at him.  He has the phone pinned between his ear and shoulder.  Kenny looks back to T.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai fixes Zorin in his seat, his voice rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Zorin, I remind you that the other day you did not deny the existence of these weapons.  But today, again, if I heard you correctly, you now say they do not exist. Zorin, headphones on, listens to his own translation, but doesn't respond, acts bored.  It gets Adlai's goat, and h begins to lose his cool.  A rumble from the U.N.  The CAM FINDS Adlai's hand SHAKING, gripping his pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM is worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Adlai, don't let him off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John?  It's Bobby.  Get ready to send your staffer in.  He's going to be coming out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Adlai's tremors are not tremors of fear.  They are tremors of anger.  His voice goes hard and cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, sir.  Let me ask you one simple question.  Do you, Ambassador Zorin, deny that the U.S.S.R. has placed and is placing medium and intermediate range missiles and sites in Cuba?  Yes or no - don't wait for the translation - yes or no? The diplomatic world GASPS as Adlai drops all pretense of civility, all statesman-like grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM's excitement mounts.  In the chorus urging Adlai on find Kenny edge toward the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zorin shoots Adlai a testy look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not in an American courtroom, sir, and therefore I do not wish to answer a question that is put to me in the fashion in which a prosecutor puts questions.  In due course, sir, you will have your answer. There's laughter at Zorin's refusal to be bullied: but it nervous laughter, not the polite stuff of diplomatic tete tete.  The RUMBLE in the room grows louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are in the courtroom of world opinion right now, and you can answer yes or no.  You have denied they exist, and I want to know if I have understood you correctly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM ROARS!  Fists in the air!  Bobby lets the phone dan a beat, covers it.  And then he lifts it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, I'll get back to you. He lowers the phone to the receiver.  Kenny shoots him a triumphant smile.  The President looks at Kenny, shakes h head, a big smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adlai presses on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm prepared to present the evidence in this room, proving that the Soviet Union has lied to the world. And Zorin cracks.  He looks uneasily to his delegation. bend forward to consult.  Adlai sits back in his chair, draping his arms over its wings with the confidence of someone who knows he's kicked ass. Adlai looks around the room while he's waiting for his answer, managing not to smile.  The diplomatic world is scandalized.  At last Zorin regroups, lifts his head from huddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you do not choose to continue your statement, the Chair recognizes the representative from Chile. The CHILEAN DELEGATE stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I yield my time and the floor to the representative to the United States. The room explodes in laughter.  Not just nervous any more not just polite.  They're laughing at Zorin's parliamenta ploy blowing up in his face.  Zorin's smile is gone, his smooth facade destroyed.  And looks like the biggest fool in the world. Adlai stares at the beet-faced man with disdain.  At last Adlai stands, gestures to the door to the hall behind him The PHOTO INTERPRETERS come racing in with their briefing boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, ladies and gentlemen, since it appears we might be here for a while, shall we have a look at what the Soviets are doing in Cuba? The Delegates RUMBLE in interest, rise from their seats t approach Adlai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM celebrates.  Phones ring at several of the chairs a the conference table. The President and Kenny meet as Bun picks up a phone in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't know Adlai had it in him.  Too bad he didn't have this stuff in '52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zorin must not have gotten instructions.  Somebody in their Foreign Ministry's blown it big-time. Bundy steps forward, holding the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President... Kenny and the President turn to see what they already hav heard in those two words: concern.  The room falls quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone in hand, McNamara paces at his post over the flag p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the ship is called Groznyy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soviet Tanker, Groznyy, breasts the heavy seas.  Arme CREWMEN race along the deck to makeshift sandbagged emplacements in the bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost track of it yesterday at nightfall.  We thought we gave it plenty of room when we moved the quarantine line back.  We just reacquired it. The CAMERA PANS to the left, revealing a U.S. DESTROYER racing up alongside a few hundred yards away, pounding up over the swells, punching up a huge fan of spray from its bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It crossed the line hours ago. Admiral Anderson, on the phone on the level below, is ten

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hail them again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep us posted, Bob. McNamara leans against the wall, closes his eyes in exhaustion and stress.  And when he opens the, we PAN ARO

dialogues.speaker: TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: A G-d-like view of the flag plot, covered with HUNDREDS O SHIPS, PLANES AND MARKINGS. McNamara stares out at the bewildering tangle of symbols, living men behind each one.  Each tangle of red and blue symbols a powderkeg.  A G-dlike view indeed.  And it is f more than any one mere man could keep control of. And he begins to realize it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're kidding ourselves... And not only that, in his bleary, sleep-deprived fog, he begins to understand something happening down there. The CAMERA MOVES over the enormous map, over the scrollin cryptic numerology.  THE BUZZ of radio communications ble in from the background.  The overhead platform swivels on motor, like the vast arm of some fate-writing god as the Watch Officer on it updates the movements of the ships. McNamara stares, at the verge of grasping something.  Thr the door-crack of genius, he has the glimpse of some gran thing, some grander design.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well.  Load your guns. That starts McNamara from his fatigued reverie.  He goes the railing, looks down on Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that, Admiral? Anderson turns, gazes up from his tier below, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been hailing the Groznyy for the last hour, Mr. Secretary.  The Groznyy refuses to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying out our mission, Mr. Secretary.  If you don't mind, we're very busy right now.  We need to be able to do our jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral, I asked you a question. Anderson holds the phone aside, turns around again, looks at him, impatient.  His answer is hard, cold, dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to follow the Rules of Engagement.  The Rules of Engagement which the President has approved and signed in his order of October 23rd. Anderson listens again to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain, you may proceed.  Clear your guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Destroyer's forward 5-inch twin guns swivel, train on Groznyy.  A beat.  They OPEN FIRE with an ear-splitting BAMBAM, ripping the air in front of the muzzles, the Groz so close a miss isn't possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McNamara SHOUTS at Anderson, dropping down the steps to Anderson's level.

dialogues.speaker: GODDAMNIT, STOP THAT FIRING
dialogues.text: Watch Officers scramble to comply, chaos and shouting in war room as a chorus if "Cease fire cease fire cease fire goes up.  McNamara turns on Anderson, is in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, God help us. Anderson smashes the phone down, wheels on McNamara, furi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Destroyer's guns hammer away at the Groznyy, at point blank range... but the Groznyy IS UNHARMED.   Suddenly, in the air above it appear BRILLIANT FLARES.  T light up the ship, brighter than the sun.  The destroyer isn't firing deadly rounds... it's firing harmless starshells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson gets in McNamara's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ship was firing starshells.  Starshells.  Flares, Mr. Secretary. Everyone's eyes are on the two men.  Only the chatter of teletype breaks the paralyzing silence.  McNamara blinks, looks down at the plot on the floor.  Anderson's voice dr to a deadly sotto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammitt, I've got a job to do.  You've been camped out up there since Monday night.  You're exhausted and you're making mistakes.  Interfere with me, you will get some of killed.  I will not allow that. McNamara looks away at the faces of the men in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starshells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of our way, Mr. Secretary.  The navy has been running blockades since the days of John Paul Jones. McNamara turns back.  And all trepidation, embarrassment, hesitation are gone.  He coldly appraises Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe the President made it clear that there would be no firing on ships without his express permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Mr. Secretary, we were not firing on the ship.  Firing on a ship means attacking the ship.  We were not attacking the ship.  We were firing over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was not the President's intention when he gave that order.  What if the Soviets don't see the distention?  What if they make the same mistake I just did? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be no firing anything near ANY Soviet ships without my express permission, is that understood, Admiral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I will only issue such instructions when ordered to by the President. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Paul Jones... you don't understand a thing, do you, Admiral? He passes his hand over the enormous plot below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a blockade. McNamara, trembling with anger, awe, whirls to Anderson. his burgeoning insight is born - clear, hard and cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This, all this, is language, a new vocabulary the likes of which the world has never seen.  This is President Kennedy communicating with Secretary Khruschev. McNamara JABS HIS FINGER OUT AT the plot, and -- -- the CAMERA RACES DOWN, TRACKING OVER IT, across the va ebb and flow of information, the delicate ballet of symbo and numerology, this language of steel and human life.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: On Kenny's T.V. Walter Cronkite reads the news to footage a BOARDING PARTY going up a ladder to the freighter MARCU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At 7:29 this morning, the U.S.S. Joseph Kennedy stopped and boarded the Soviet charter vessel Marcula. The Boarding Party wears dress whites and is UNARMED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a 3-hour inspection, the Kennedy signaled no contraband found.  Cleared to continue.  Pentagon spokesmen expect the next encounter. Kenny, who turns from the T.V. as the door to his office opens.  Rusk walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, we need to see the President.  Something's happened. Kenny reacts to Rusk's enigmatic expression.  And out fro behind Rusk steps JOHN SCALI, the ABC News Correspondent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF THEIR REACTIONS, the CAMERA FINDS an under-strength, hoc EXCOM - Kenny, Bobby, Taylor, Bundy, Sorensen, McCone Ball and the President.  Guarded hope all around.  The sh balding, pugnacious Scali looks discomfited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
