dialogues.text: I have lunch with him maybe once a month.  Way he talks, he acts like he knows Khruschev personally, but he's never elaborated.  I've used him as a source in a couple of stories. Kenny paces behind the gathered men around the President' desk, listening, mind going a million miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FBI has identified this Alexander Fomin as the Soviet Resident, the KGB equivalent of one of our station chiefs.  He's their highest ranking spy in this country.  And he knows John's a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the trademarks of a back-channel overture. Kenny eyes Bundy, makes him uncomfortable.  The President sizes Scali up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they'll remove the missiles, and we'll pledge not to invade Cuba, destabilize Castro or assist anyone who plans in doing so... Nobody dares speak.  It's as if the possibility of a settlement will vanish into thin air if anyone moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think... this may be our first real message from Khruschev.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alternative, Mr. President, is that this could be a trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dangle a settlement, tie us down in negotiations, we come up short...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why else would they approach us in this way?  It's deniable.  The Soviets have done nothing but lie to us.  This could be more of the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be why Khruschev's introducing this guy.  We've been burned by his usual players in the formal channels, so he brings in an honest broker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be what they want us to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, Mr. President, we don't even really know whom Fomin speaks for.  It could be Khruschev. It could be some faction in the Politburo or the KGB itself.  We just don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, Scali, your activities now fall under the secrecy codicils of the National Security Act.  Sorry, no Pulitzer. The gathered men chuckle, only Scali a bit dour but being good sport about it.  Scali checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, we don't have much time.  I'm supposed to meet with him again in three and a half hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it seems the question of the day is -- is the offer legitimate? He moves away from his desk.  The men watch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is... if it is, then we can't afford to ignore it. (beat, to Scali)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, we'll have instructions for you in a couple of hours. Scali nods.  Rusk escorts him out.  They wait until the d closes.  Taylor looks over at McCone who nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I'm afraid we have some bad news.  We're getting GMAIC estimates from our latest low-level overflights.  It appears the missiles are two to three days away from operational status.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we don't have much time to play out back-channel communiques. Kenny gives Bobby a hard look.  The President appears unfazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quarantine, sir, is not producing results.  The Chiefs feel it's time you take another look at our options. The President considers Taylor, then looks over to Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, get over to your old stomping grounds.  Go through everything the FBI has on Fomin.  I need your best call: is this guy legit and is he speaking for Khruschev?  And I need you to tell me by the time I call you, because right after I call you, I'm calling Scali with his instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG!  A STACK OF FILES slams down beside Kenny on a larg paper-covered conference table.  WALTER SHERIDAN, Kenny's investigator-buddy, wears a visitor's pass just like Kenn Kenny and Walter RIFLE through the folders, super fast, s proficient.  A half-dozen FBI AGENTS work around the tabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  So, what we've got is this guy Alexander Feklisov, aka Alexander Fomin, declared Consul to the Soviet Embassy, but in reality the KGB Papa Spy.  An illustrious tour of duty during the Great Patriotic War gets him on the Party fast track, various tours of duty in KGB, American postings.  He's an expert on us, and... that's all we've got on Papa Spy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he talking for?  Is it Khruschev, or is this more bullshit? Kenny stands, runs his hands through his hair, aggravated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you become the KGB top spy in the United States?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta know someone. Kenny whirls on Sheridan.  A frozen beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Politics is politics.  Walter. (whirling on Agents)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khruschev is the Moscow Party Boss under Stalin.  Give me their career chronologies! Walter pushes a typed dateline of Khruschev's major caree moves, and one of the Agents hands Kenny a list of Fomin' postings.  He lays them side by side.  And for every step Khruschev's, there's a step for Fomin.  Not only that, bu the DATES ARE IDENTICAL or nearly so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time Khruschev moves up, Fomin does within a year... (tracing up the list)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khruschev was the administrator in charge of preparing Moscow's defenses during the war.  And Fomin... was here in the U.S. Kenny's face falls.  But a YOUNG FBI AGENT cuts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at first. The Young FBI Agent proffers him a file.  Kenny snatches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was an engineer stationed outside Moscow in '42.  Specialized in tank traps. Kenny looks up at Walter.  Walter nods sagely, lights a p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know each other.  They're war buddies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's thin.  But real life usually is. A PHONE on the table SHRILLS, shattering the silent trium

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to move.  What do you have, Kenny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know each other!  Khruschev and Feklisov aka Fomin were war buddies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it to court, but we've got good circumstantial evidence... (off Walter's nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter agrees.  My gut's telling me Khruschev's turning to a trusted old friend to carry his message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ken.  We're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few lonely BUSINESS TRAVELERS hang out in the dim coffe shop.  Faint music plays.  Scali and ALEXANDER FOMIN sit steaming cups of coffee.  Scali, nervous, unfolds a note. Fomin, an expressionless gray spectre of a man, eyes him. is, in his boredom, a spy's spy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am instructed to tell you that the American Government would respond favorably to an offer along the lines you have discussed.  If this solution were raised at the U.N. by Ambassador Zorin, he would find a favorable reply from Ambassador Stevenson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I understand you correctly.  If the missiles in Cuba were dismantled, returned to the Soviet Union, and a guarantee was made not to reintroduce them, the United States would be prepared to guarantee that it would never invade Cuba?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is from the Highest Authority?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  From the Highest Authority.  There are two conditions.  The U.N. must be allowed to inspect the removal of the missiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, of course, the U.N. must be allowed to observe the redeployment of forces from the American Southeast. Scali demurs.  He has no instructions on this count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the second condition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time is of the essence. Scali takes a sip of coffee.  Fomin stares at him, intens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John.  How much time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 hours.  In 48 hours there can be no deals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scali finishes debriefing the President, Bobby, Kenny, McCone, Taylor and Bundy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left right away.  Got the feeling he meant business. Kenny and Bobby share a hopeful glance.  Rusk enters from Kenny's office.  And he's unable to contain his excitemen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, we're receiving a letter from Khruschev over at State.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a cluster of folding metal chairs, Kenny, Bobby, Rus and Sorensen watch a TELETYPE hammer out the message as i comes off the wire.  It's painfully slow, like watching a typist type a manuscript.  Ten pages of this is an eterni To top it off, it's in Russian.  A TRANSLATOR reads it of word by word to a TRANSCRIBER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...two...of...us...pull...on...the... knot...of...war...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny slams a page of Khruschev's letter on the table.  H jabs his finger at it.  EXCOM listens, intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ten pages of sentimental fluff, but he's saying right here.  He'll remove the missiles in return for a no-invasion pledge.  It looks like Fomin's overture was genuine. The President turns to McCone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our early analysis says this was probably written by Khruschev himself.  It's a first draft, and shows no signs of being polished by the foreign ministry.  In fact, it probably hasn't been approved by the Politburo.  They wouldn't have let the emotionalism go by.  The analysts say it was written by someone under considerable stress. EXCOM chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to hear we're not alone. The President eyes the EXCOM members one by one, an incip smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, I wasn't planning on invading Cuba anyway.  I think we can live with the terms of this deal. There are mostly nods of assent, big smiles around the ta Except from  McCone and Taylor.  The President takes his of the letter, flips through it.  He shakes his head, alm unable to believe that Khruschev has given in.  A long be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, I want you to draft our acceptance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, black car stops at the end of Kenny's driveway. door opens, and Kenny steps out.  He says an inaudible goodnight to the driver, and the car pulls off.  He turns facing the white two-story house with the neat front yard the lights out.  And he smiles.  Home at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A screen door squeaks open.  Kenny steps out into the darkness of the back yard.  And there, in her robe, sitti startled on a lawn chair, lit only by the dim glow of the kitchen window, is Helen.  Kenny stands there tired, his slung over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Helen rises, her own care-worn face turned to his.  For a silent moment they gaze at each other, searching in the l of each others' face for the changes of a long separation They see them.  But they've been married a long time, and awkwardness passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, O'Donnell.  You look old. Kenny drops his coat on a table as Helen comes up and fol herself into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This job's going to kill you.  If I don't first. They kiss, comfortable.  But not too long, and he lets he go.  She looks at him again, sees he's suppressing a smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're home it means either Jack and Bobby have finally figured out what a con man you are and fired you, or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- we got a back channel communication from Khruschev this evening feeling us out about a deal.  He confirmed it just a little while ago in a letter to the President.  I think we've won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thing like this... who could even think of winning?

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Kenny, in his overcoat, steps aside as a pair of Duty Officers race past him, almost bowling him over.  He slows as he nears the doors to his office and the Oval Office, DISCOVERING: TOTAL CHAOS.  EXCOM guys, Assistants, dart to and from th offices and halls.  On all their faces grim expressions.  Kenny stands there a beat in confusion.  And then Bobby swings out of Kenny's office.  There's a desperate edge t Bobby's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where've you been?  We've been trying to find you all morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen and I went out for breakfast. EXCOM's not supposed to convene til eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just got a second letter from Khruschev.  The deal's off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and Bobby walk fast for the cabinet room, Kenny sti in his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're getting everyone together as fast as we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does the letter say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want us to take our missiles out of Turkey along with the no invasion pledge.  It looks like Fomin was a ploy after all, and they were just stalling for time. Kenny is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gets worse. Kenny gives Bobby a sharp look as they enter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President, in shirtsleeves, no tie, glances up at Ken as he and Bobby enter.  Kenny can only bear his look for second: he blew the call on Fomin.  But the President is clearly relieved to see him, gives him a faint smile.  Half of EXCOM, including McNamara, McCone, Rusk, and Tayl barely notice them as they're already there arguing. Kenny sits down hurriedly, shucks off his coat as he join the conversation in mid-stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My specialists are in agreement: this morning's letter is not Khruschev.  Last night's letter was. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evidence supports only one conclusion: there has been a coup, and Khruschev was replaced overnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ... Bobby gives him a look: told you things got worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't necessarily mean there's been a coup.  Khruschev's name is signed to the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on, Dean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But at the very least... It does suggest he's been co-opted by hard line elements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which at the end of the day is the same thing as a coup.  A puppet Khruschev, and a hard-line Soviet government pulling the strings.  No deal.  And the missiles are almost operational. Bitter silence.  They all look to the President.  Imminen victory has turned to ashes.  The President studies his o folded hands.  Ball and Thompson enter, take seats.  One one, throughout the scene, other EXCOM members join the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, the problem we have is that this is latest offer of theirs will seem reasonable to everyone.  We remove our missiles, they remove theirs.  Our Jupiters were scheduled for removal anyway.  They're obsolete, after all. Kenny shakes his head in mute anger.  McNamara and Rusk s to sense the President's feelings, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, agreeing to such a trade would be tantamount to paying ransom.  They'll put a gun to our head again, and expect us to pay again. Kenny looks the President in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't sell out one of our friends for our own safety.  NATO wouldn't trust us anymore, and they'd be right not to. The President sighs in the face of the stern advice.  He nods, expecting as much.  Bobby still can't look at anyon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So which one of you geniuses can tell me how to explain ourselves to the world?  How do we work with them if there's been a hard-line coup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, there is another possibility we haven't considered.  This may not be a coup at all. Everyone of Kenny's instincts jumps.  His head snaps up t listen to Taylor.  Taylor pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible that the back-channel overture, last night's letter, and this letter today, along with everything the Soviets have said all along, is nothing more than a lie -- disinformation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Designed to keep us from taking action. Kenny hears the fatalism in McNamara's voice.  A long bea Everyone stares at McNamara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to say it, but if I had to bet, I'd bet Max is right.  What if they have no intention of honoring this deal, either?  Then tomorrow they add another condition.  Meanwhile, the quarantine isn't working and they're continuing to work on the missile sites. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we have to consider issuing warning orders for our forces. They were so close last night... and suddenly Lundahl and LeMay enter the room with the day's briefing boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President... Lundahl stands there at the end of the table, gray.  He almost can't say it, can't look the President in the face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning's photography is in.  It appears the Soviets have commenced a crash program to ready the missiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The missiles site is now more than just dirt and clearing equipment.  It's an armed camp, with missiles, fuel trail erectors spaced every few hundred yards.  MISSILE TECHNIC service the towering SS-4s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first missiles became operational last night. With a barrage of shouted orders in Russian, and a whine the ERECTOR's engines, THE MISSILE BEGINS TO RISE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We expect they'll all be operational in 36 hours: Monday morning. It stops, vertical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news hits the room like a thunderbolt.  Kenny looks t Bobby and the President.  The blood is gone from their fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we're out of time.  We have to go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may not be as easy as we thought either.  We've gotten confirmation that the Soviets have also deployed battlefield nuclear weapons to Cuba.  A pall falls over the room as LeMay explains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROGS, we call 'em.  Short range tactical nukes.  It's possible they've delegated release authority to their local commanders for use against our invasion troops.  It'd be standard doctrine. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our capability to get all the missiles has eroded during our delay with the quarantine.  The good news is that for the moment we know where the FROGS are, and we can target them, too.  But the longer we wait, the hard it's going to get. They all look to the President.  Kenny stares, in a priva hell, blacker and more complete than anyone should ever k In that shocked silence each man grapples with failure. Best and the Brightest could not prevent what must come n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we have no choice. (to  Taylor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, issue the warning orders to our forces.  They will be prepared to execute the air strikes Monday morning and the follow-on invasion according to the schedule thereafter.  I'll need the official release orders on my desk Sunday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understood, sir.  We need to step up the overflights, finalize our pilots' target folders in order to be able to carry out the strikes. The President gives Kenny a meaningful look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permission granted. Taylor exits.  Kenny rises, gives the President an almost imperceptible nod, as he prepares to leave in Taylor's wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, if anybody's got any great ideas, now's the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAJOR RUDOLPH ANDERSON, 30, wearing the bulky high-altitu pressure suit of a U-2 pilot, takes the phone from one of Air Force NCOs who are helping him suit up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Major Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, at the other end of the line, stares out the windo the fall day.  It seems so mild, so unlike war.  And it t him a beat before he realizes Anderson's on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Anyone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, my name is Kenneth O'Donnell.  Special Assistant to the President. Kenny takes a breath, ready to start the shuck-and-jive.. but for some reason doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, a few days ago the President ordered me to help him keep control of what's going on out there.  I've been browbeating pilots, navy guys left and right to make sure you don't get us here in Washington into trouble.  But you know what?  We're pretty damn good at getting ourselves into trouble.  So instead of riding your ass, I'm just going to tell you what's going on, and let you figure out how best to help us out up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now mostly suited up, Major Anderson takes the phone out the NCO's hand.  He nods, serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night, we looked like we were going to cut a deal to get us all out of this mess.  Today, the Soviets are reneging.  We're going to try to salvage the situation, but a lot of things are going wrong today.  It's making everyone nervous, and it will be very hard to avoid going to war.  Don't get shot down, Major.  Beyond that, whatever else you can do to help us, I'd really appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Anderson waves his NCOs away.  They leave the room. The Major sits on a bench in front of his locker, thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're up there at 72,000 feet, there's a million things that can go wrong.  Is your oxygen mix right?  Will your cameras freeze up?  Are you leaving contrail... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those million things are beyond your control, mostly... But you know, when you realize that, there's a kind of peace.  You don't need to be in control.  You never were in control in the first place.  If you're a good man, and your ground crew are good men, it's all you can ask for.  And with the grace of G-d, it'll get you through. The young Major smiles to himself, to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like a good man.  You'll be all right, Mr. O'Donnell.  We believe in you guys down here. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny nods to himself, deeply touched by the man's faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a click, the line goes dead and Anderson walks the p over to the receiver on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cart speeds down the tarmac, an NCO behind the wheel.  Beside him sits Major Anderson, his helmet on, visor up. adjusts the mix on the oxygen bottle he's carrying at his feet, breathing in preparation for the high-altitude flig Up ahead, among a host of service vehicles, sits the U-2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson switches over to the U-2's oxygen supply as his belt him in.  They slap him on the helmet for good luck a lower the canopy as he brings his engines up to power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is flight G3132, requesting permission for take-off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G3132, you've got runway one, you are cleared to proceed to Angels 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger that. And he throws the throttle forward,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twilight, in-between, world of the stratosphere.  Far below -- clouds, shining blue day.  Above, stars and the indigo depths of space.  We hang in utter silence. A silver glint appears in the center of the horizon.  It grows larger.  Then larger still.  It is the U-2.  We bar have time to register the rising hiss of its engines, whe FILLS THE SCREEN and BOOMS PAST, leaving us standing stil The CAMERA PANS to follow it, but it's already dwindled t speck, and we feel how fast 600 miles an hour really is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's gloved hand reaches for the CAMERA HEATER switches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The belly door whines open like a silver eyelid, exposing camera's lense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson double checks his position, switches to the autopilot for the stability only the machine can provide, then hits the CAMERA ACTIVATE button on his joystick.  BAMABMABMABMA... The camera begins its photography. Anderson watches the number on the film-remaining counter spool down.  He stares out the window.  The towering clou below rise up magnificent, glorious... a glimpse of heave Rapt,  Anderson stares.  And then suddenly a BLARING ALAR GOES OFF IN THE COCKPIT.  It shocks Anderson around to th controls.  It's his MISSILE WARNING LIGHT. Anderson' hands flash out to the joystick, turning off th cameras, disabling autopilot.  He banks the U-2 hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the U-2 turns, far, far below, emerging from the cloud barely visible, rises a CONTRAIL.  It arcs lazily toward A beat, and then another CONTRAIL.   Then ANOTHER.  The anti-aircraft missiles creating them a too small to be seen with the naked eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cockpit is a cacophony of alarms and lights, the hori outside tilted.  Anderson's breath comes fast, rasping as does his strains going into the high-g turn. He looks out the cockpit window, finds the first SA-2 mis in pursuit only several thousand feet below him now.  He waits. Waits.  Waits, still in the turn.  The black head the missile now visible. He puts the plane over, rolling out into an opposite bank

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spy plane's long flimsy wings weren't made for dogfighting.  They BEND terribly in the rollout.  And the the first missile STREAKS past, tries to correct its miss but can't and vanishes into the distance at a 90-degree angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's breath comes faster and faster as the second missile rises up, now visible.  He puts the throttle as f as it goes, trying to outrun death.  Every second is a te of a mile, and every mile shortens the missile's life spa The rising missile drafts aft, closing on the U-2 from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second missile's contrail rises up behind the plane, levels off, and closes on it at a tremendous rate. The third missile rises up in the far distance behind the second. The second missile races up on the U-2, closer, right beh it, can't miss.  Then at a hundred yards, the contrail suddenly peters out, and the missile, out of fuel, drops away. But the third missile closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson glances out the window, sees the spent missiles away, and spots the third missile still seeking him aft.  Hand pinning the throttle forward, he prays under his bre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third SA-2 rides its billowing column of exhaust stra for the tail of the U-2.  This one is not out of fuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Anderson opens his eyes.  He stares out the window the glorious wonder of cloud and sea and earth below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the missile looms.  We have time to realize it's almo as big as the plane itself before it SHEARS right into th 2's tail and EXPLODES in a BLINDING FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny, jogging down the hall, hears form an open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny! Kenny goes over to the threshold.  Inside the office Bund stands up from behind his desk, grave.  And Kenny knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of EXCOM is there except for Bundy.  Kenny sits behin the President, deeply distraught over Major Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this attack on our plane represent a definitive, intentional escalation on the part of the Soviets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soviets are in control of the SAMs.  It's hard to believe with their centralized command structure that it could be an accidental launch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, taken with the events of the past few hours, I believe this confirms our worst fears.  We're now dealing with a hard-line Soviet government, perhaps with Khruschev as a puppet head, perhaps not. In the silence, Kenny reads the faces around the room.  They're convinced by McCone's pronouncement.  Kenny's not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be a mistake. McCone gives him a get-serious look.  But Kenny presses o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to be positive before we react. Bundy enters the room.  Everyone looks up.  He stands the in the doorway, his face tight. Kenny sags in his chair.  Bundy, of course, has more bad news, and they all know it.  A hopeless beat.  The Presid just stares at Bundy, unable to ask.  Bundy nods, affirmi what everyone is thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A U-2 on a routine air-sampling mission over Siberia got lost and penetrated Soviet airspace.  The Soviets scrambled MIGs in pursuit, thinking it was a bomber.  It got out okay.  Somebody forgot to cancel the mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammitt.  There's always some sonofabitch who doesn't get the word.  All we need is the Soviets thinking we're bombing them. (facetious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody else? The humor falls on a cold audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, our pilots are in danger.  We must order punitive airstrikes against the SAM site that shot down Major Anderson per our rules of engagement. And finally the moment Kenny has dreaded all this time ha come to pass.  He looks at Bobby, then at the President. President stares at the cup of coffee in his hands, as if trying to read the Fates' design in it.  A long beat, and everyone holds their breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I want confirmation there wasn't some sort of accident first. LeMay clears his throat.  Everyone looks at him, expectin him to scream or jump up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's a good idea, Mr. President.  It'll be safer for my boys to get those SAMs on Monday when we get the rest of the bastards.  I can wait a day and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, then. But he says it without any belief in the words, realizing they're being tied fast to the train tracks of war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in his office, shattered, Kenny stares out the wind viewing the distant Ellipse through a gap in the trees. are out there playing football.  He glances at his watch, grabs his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny puts on his jacket as he goes down the steps into t bright autumn day, walking away from the White House.  It drops behind him -- his step is faster, more urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny walks down the sidewalk, drawn toward the Ellipse. sixth grade FOOTBALL PLAYERS sweep forward with a running play.  Kenny scans them, searching, his breath coming har

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the edge of the open field.  And then he spots name on the jersey: O'Donnell.  It's Kevin. The players relinquish the ball and the offense comes off the field.  Kevin sees his dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Dad! Kenny manages a smile as Kevin trots over.  Kevin pulls h helmet off.  They stand there a long beat, Kenny desperat take him up, abandon his post... but he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sport.  You winning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But Kevin sees the turmoil in his father's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything going to be okay, Dad? Kenny's forced smile is answer enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Kev.  Everything's gonna be fine. But Kevin knows.  Together they know.  The end of the wor is at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you won't be coming home tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh... Suddenly a car HONKS.  Kenny turns around.  Bobby is lean out the rear passenger window of his limo.  And he sees w Kenny is doing.  He doesn't want to cut in, but has to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny!  We need to talk. Kenny looks back at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back out there, kid.  Remember to hit 'em hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?  Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to work. Kevin puts his helmet back on his head.  Kenny watches as Kevin jogs off to rejoin his team.  Kenny turns his back his son, and strides for Bobby's limo, dying inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and Bobby stand by their car off to one side of the restaurant's parking lot.  Bobby's Secret Service Agents maintain a discreet distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're going to make a deal, we're going to have to do it fast.  This is only getting out of control.  The only reason we're not at war this very minute is he's been able to stretch, bend and break his own rules.  He won't be able to keep it up forever. Bobby jams the last bit of sandwich in his mouth.  A beat Kenny looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jack wants to trade the missiles in Turkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jupiters are obsolete.  They were supposed to have been dismantled last summer anyway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Jesus, Mary and Joseph.  I told you how stupid it was to float the Lippman article!  But you wouldn't listen to me.  What if there hasn't been a coup at all?  What if it's you two who invited that second letter by raising the possibility of a trade? Bobby is speechless with rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if the two of you are thinking this trade is your ace in the hole, you're so wrong.  It's a deuce. Bobby's beyond furious.  They catch their rising voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's not just me who thinks that.  Everyone on this so-called EXCOM is telling you exactly the same thing: make the trade, and they're going to force us into trade after trade until finally they demand something we won't trade like Berlin, and we do end up in a war. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to mention, that long before that happens, this government will be politically dead. Bobby simmers for a long beat, thinking.  And boy, does t guy hate admitting he's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, so maybe we overestimated how reasonable this trade would look.  Okay?  You happy?  So now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now you've got to talk him out of it.  And then we've got to figure out an acceptable political solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if there has been a coup and there is no acceptable political solution? Kenny stares off at the city, agonized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny enters from his office, finding Bobby, Rusk and Sorensen talking with the President.  The President gives a brief, meaningful look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever response we send, it will take several hours for the wire to be received by our embassy and delivered to the Kremlin.  So we're looking at early tomorrow morning at the earliest before Khruschev could respond. As Rusk talks, Kenny passes close by Bobby.  Bobby whispe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets it, but he's pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all well and good, but what do we say to 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends on if we really believe there's been a coup. That strikes a cord with Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.  If there has been a coup, and there's a hard-line government in power now, then it doesn't matter what we say.  The end of the day we'll either agree to their terms, they'll agree to ours, or we'll go to war.  But what if there hasn't been a coup?  What if... what if what is happening is a series of accidents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second letter is an accident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  The letter is an intentional, but it's having an effect far greater than its authors intended. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if our Jupiter missiles are just a last minute haggle to salvage something?  Maybe a bone Khruschev is throwing to the hard line, not really caring if we reject it or not? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then these accidents have happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making the second letter and the overall picture look worse than it really is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guns of August.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they're sane and human like we are, then maybe we just refuse, and they'll let it slide, like we've been letting things slide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we reject the second letter. And Kenny looks at Bobby.  The world stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  We don't reject it... It hits Bobby like a lightning bolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We accept the first letter and pretend the second doesn't exist. The President, Rusk and Sorensen stare at him, mute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON the exact same mute reaction from the entire assembled EXCOM.  Finally McCone breaks the spell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't work -- Bobby, Kenny and Sorensen start to object, but McCone rai his voice over theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- because it's wishful thinking!  It's the same wishful thinking that blinded us all these months while the Soviets were sneaking those missiles in under our noses! McNamara shakes his head, intrigued but skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignore the second letter, agree to the conditions of the first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no reason to believe the Soviets will let it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is right.  Why will they accept it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can work.  If, IF they believe we'll hit them. Kenny, Bobby and Sorensen look at McNamara, grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've only got time for one more round of diplomacy.  The first airstrikes start in less than 36 hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we have to make them agree to it.  So how do we do that? The President leans forward.  Sensing he's about to speak all eyes turn to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We give them something.  We tell them we'll remove the missiles from Turkey say, six months from now so that there appears to be no linkage.  We also tell them if they go public about it, we deny it and the deal is off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we do it under the table so we can disavow any knowledge of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's transparent.  The press'll be all over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months from now, I'm not going to care.  Are you?  We'll deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least it will expose whether Khruschev has been overthrown.  We'll know what we're dealing with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if this is a move to appease the hard line, then it may just be the bone he needs to regain control of his own house. Most EXCOM is nodding, agreeing.  McCone shakes his head disgust.  Taylor sits in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever carries the message has to hit the nail on the head.  Come across as too soft, they'll push us.  Too hard, they'll be cornered and even more dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could pre-empt. It's a terrible responsibility to bear.  The room is sile At last Bobby looks up from his folded hands to his broth The President stares back.  There is nobody else who can this.  Only Bobby. His brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby.  You know Dobrynin best. Bobby nods, taking up the gauntlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, you get working on the draft. Sorensen and Bobby rise as one, head for the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And make sure he knows we have to have an answer tomorrow. (beat, final)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because on Monday we begin military action against Cuba. Bobby and Kenny exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG SHOT: Bobby emerges from the West Wing in his overcoat, briefcase in hand.  He pauses, tiny, alone.  Th West Wing - and all its imposing spotlit power behind him reduced to this insignificant man on his eleventh-hour mission. And then, out of the shadows, in the f.g., steps Kenny in own coat, his breath frosting in the late-night air.  Bob sees him, and knows he is not so alone anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: They meet in front of the limo.  Bobby stops, shuffles hi things, awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?  A good-bye kiss? Kenny opens the driver's side door.  The Secret Service L DRIVER peers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joe.  Listen, I'll take care of him.  Go ahead in, grab some coffee.  We'll be back pretty quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure? Kenny's nod and look -- there's no arguing.  The Limo Dri hops out, and Kenny gets in.  Bobby stands there outside a beat.  He tries to hide how touched he is, but can't completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?  Forget how to open a car door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby recovers, opens his own door, gets in the front sea next to Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you rich people. Kenny starts up the engine.  Bobby smiles a twisted smile As the car pulls away, the two men sit in silence, neithe willing to admit how glad the other is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo wheels out into the street, carrying the two fri into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby stares out the window at the passing city, the ligh the lives behind those windows.  As the car drives on and the tension returns.  Bobby feels the weight of all those lives.  On him.  A long beat.  He gazes at Kenny, the onl man he could ever admit this to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can do this. Kenny glances over at him.  Bobby stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nobody else I'd rather have going in there. Bobby looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody else I'd trust Helen and the kids' lives to. Kenny means it.  He looks away.  Bobby shifts, awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a left. Kenny looks him.  This isn't the way to the Justice Department.  But he complies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gave so much to get here.  I don't know.  Sometimes I think what the hell did we do it for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we knew we could do a better job than everyone else. And Bobby, in the silence and closeness of the car, turns Kenny - anguished, knowing his life is at its climax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... I hate being called the brilliant one.  The ruthless one.  They guy who does the dirty work.  The one everybody's afraid of.   Kenny looks to him, moved, not knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it.  I'm not smart, you know.  And I'm not so ruthless. He looks to Kenny, searching his face, then away, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right about the smart part, but ruthless, well... That breaks the tension as they arrive at the scene:

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Appears the grim, square lines of the SOVIET EMBASSY.  Po cars line the streets outside it.  All the windows are da A cordon of KGB GUARDS in plainclothes stand by the gated entrance.  On the opposite side of the street lounge two dozen WASHINGTON D.C. POLICE.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Kenny gives Bobby a look.  Bobby rolls down his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down.  Smell that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanted to see for myself. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're burning their documents. The final duty of an embassy before war...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think we're going to war.  G-d help us, Ken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA lifts away from the limo, turning toward the Embassy, past the Guards, past the brass plate which read EMBASSY OF THE UNITED SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS, up and to the roof where black, reeking SMOKE billows from all o the Embassy's several chimneys. The CAMERA races into it.  It engulfs us all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny squeals the limo up to the curb in front of the Jus Department.  The doors fly open, and Kenny and Bobby jump out, head up the steps to the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby's STAFFERS greet them as they stride down the hall, Staffer #1 taking Bobby's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Ambassador Dobrynin is already here.  We have him waiting in your office. They reach the double oak doors to Bobby's suite and stop Bobby faces Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll whistle up some luck for you. And before Kenny's eyes, all of Bobby's doubt vanishes. its place, a severe confidence.  A grandeur Kenny has nev seen. It makes Kenny pause.  He beholds his best friend become man of the ages.  And then Bobby SMOOTHLY opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a DOOR SHUTS OC like a threshold of history.  HOLD ON Bobby's waiting room.  Silent.  Cavernous.  Dim.  Plush carpet.  Heavy drapes framing dark windows.  And abandone secretary's desk.  A row of sofas and chairs on either si of the room.  Two doorways, one at either end of the room A WOMAN sits in one of the chairs for visitors.  Dressed gray.  Prim.  But beautiful.  A secretary of some sort. One of the double doors to the hall swings silently open. Kenny glides in.  He sees the other door shut at the far of the room.  Kenny crashes in one of the chairs to wait. HOLD ON THE SCENE, motionless, silent. Kenny WHISTLES two notes.  Stops.  And then he begins to WHISTLE the Irish tune, O'Donnell Aboo.  He gets a bar in it -- and there's a polite, soft COUGH. Kenny stops.  Then notices the Woman in gray across the r He didn't see her.  It's dim over there.  She looks at hi expressionless. The CAMERA FINDS: a pin on her lapel.  A RED HAMMER AND SICKLE. Kenny reacts.  Dobrynin's assistant?  His opposite number friend?  Or more than a friend? Here is the face of the enemy.  Not a smile between them. Kenny resumes his ease.  And begins to WHISTLE again. The haunting Irish song echoes in the vaulted ceiling, filling the dim room.  Strange, sad, beautiful.  The woma listens.  And her face begins to soften.   Kenny stares at the dark, lonely windows, his SONG strivi to fill the empty room. Kenny sinks deeper in the chair, his tune all-consuming.. and the Woman's voice breaks in.  Kenny stops, looks over Her voice is tremulous and beautiful.  Just a snatch of s song in Russian.  She stops, awkward. Kenny stares.  The Woman stares back.  No smiles.  But in their eyes, they each see the other's fear, the other's beauty, the other's humanity. So this is the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? Kenny glances to the door.  He considers for a long momen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The friend. Kenny breaks the gaze.  He begins to whistle again.  The CAMERA drifts away, finding the far DOOR to the inner off Kenny's tune stronger, carrying with it hope...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to the other side of that DOOR.  Dobrynin sits in a c opposite Bobby behind his desk.  The room is equally dim. And far more tense. Silence.  And then the FAINTEST STRAIN of O'Donnell Aboo. Dobrynin glances briefly over his shoulder at the door. But Bobby, unseen by Dobrynin, can't help the flicker of private smile.  It's Kenny's presence, and Bobby is the stronger for it.  And then the tune is gone. Bobby leans forward, cool, controlled, masterful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambassador Dobrynin, we are aware that at this moment your missiles in Cuba are at the brink of operational readiness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floodlights illuminate MISSILES, vertical on their erecto support VEHICLES, clustered across the man-made clearing. Mask-wearing Technicians wave a FUEL TRUCK back to the nearest missile.  Clouds of toxic VAPOR rise from the oth They've already been fueled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are a vital threat to my country.  If launched, they would kill 80 million Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dobrynin listens impassively, as is his professional duty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother, my friends, my countrymen and I cannot and will not permit those missiles to become operational. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise you that. Dobrynin looks out the window.  And then, pained, looks b at Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I fear our two nations will go to war.  And I fear where war will lead us. Bobby acknowledges him with a nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the missiles do not become operational, if you remove the missiles, then there will be no war. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment, the President is accepting the terms of Secretary Khruschev's letter of Friday night.  If the Soviet Union halts construction immediately, removes the missiles, and submits to U.N. inspection, the United States will pledge to never invade Cuba or aid others in that enterprise. Dobrynin stares at Bobby.  Stares hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your Jupiter missiles in Turkey were removed also, such an accommodation could be reached. The two men move their argument forward with the delibera and formality of chess masters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tired sounding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The United States cannot agree to such terms under threat.  Any belief to the contrary -- (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- was in error. Dobrynin reels internally.  The only sign on his face is slight tremor.  Bobby looks up, registers the calculated effect.  And to Dobrynin's horror, the Russian believes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want war... But not so fast.  Bobby folds his hands.  And he smoothly goes from hard-ass brinksman to sensitive deal-maker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, while there can be no quid pro quo on this issue, the United States can offer a private assurance. Dobrynin holds his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Jupiter missiles in Turkey are obsolete, and have been scheduled for withdrawal for some time.  This withdrawal should be completed within, say, six months. Dobrynin lets out his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, any public disclosure of this assurance would negate the deal and produce the most stringent denials from our government. Dobrynin grasps the move immediately, understanding the ramifications.  Still he hesitates a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This private assurance represents the word of the Highest Authority?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it can be relayed beyond Comrade Khruschev's ears to the top circles of my government

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  Our pledge can be relayed to any government official Secretary Khruschev sees fit to satisfy. Meaning this is the bone he can show the hard line.  Dobr struggles internally, knowing what Bobby has done, wantin hug him.  It comes across as agitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the caveat that it is not made public in any way, shape or form. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we must have an answer tomorrow at the latest.  I cannot stress this point enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow... Dobrynin rises from his chair.  Bobby rises with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you must excuse me and permit me to relay the substance of our discussion to my superiors. Dobrynin heads for the door.  Half way there he turns bac Bobby, deeply moved.  Deeply grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have heard stories that some among your military men wish for war. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a good man.  Your brother is a good man.  I assure you there are other good men.  Let us hope the will of good men is enough to counter the terrible strength of this thing which has been put in motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny enters the Oval Office through his side door.  The office is dark, only the desk lamp on.  Kenny's gaze move over the trappings of power: the carpet with the Presiden Seal, the rocking chair by the fireplace, the desk. And on the desk, tucked almost out of sight, sits a small humble wooden plaque.  It's turned to face the occupant o the chair behind the desk.  Kenny reaches out, turns it around.  It is the Breton's Fisherman's Prayer. It reads: OH LORD, THY SEA IS GREAT, MY BOAT SO SMALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're out here. Kenny holds on the plaque a beat, and looks up at the ope French door to the Rose Garden.  The curtains swirl aroun him in the wind as he goes through the door and out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- onto the portico.  Standing there in the dark, by the white neoclassical pillars of the cloister, are Bobby and President.  They're holding drinks.  Kenny joins them. The President gestures out across the South Lawn to the gleaming Washington Monument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just debating who had it worse, us or George Washington and his guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't have to worry about nuclear weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the country didn't even exist as a country yet.  It was a mess, and he didn't have a leg to stand on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All he had was his character. The President and Bobby nod at the justice of that remark

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does a guy get a rep like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter to me.  If I went down in history like Adams, I'd die happy.  All they say about him today is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- he kept the peace. Kenny looks at the President.  The President feels it, an gazes back to him. The three of them stare out at the glittering city.  The grandness of the world lies before them, and they are deciding its fate, and are humbled by the awfulness of it The silence is beyond power. And for a long moment, they know not to disturb it.  Ther nothing left to say.  The President, at last, finishes hi drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, we never did control it.  Not really.  Not like we think. He looks at Kenny.  Kenny nods.  He knows that now too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we did our best.  Now it's up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny's limo pulls away, leaving Kenny, coat in hand, at bottom of his driveway.  He watches it go, silently urgin to return for him with some call from the President telli him he's desperately needed.  But it doesn't. He turns to his house.  The lights are all out. He notices he's CLUTCHING the handle of his briefcase.  H knuckles are white.  With conscious effort, he unfolds hi hand, letting the briefcase drop on the driveway. He stands alone, stripped of his friends, his family, his job... and in that moment, mute, impotent in the shadow o Armageddon, Kenny is our Everyman of the Nuclear Age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen stands in the kitchen, a ghostly white figure in he robe, the windows open and curtain flapping as she breath the air.  Kenny enters.  He stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you out there.  You want him to call you back, need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm glad I'm home. And she knows the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do we have? Kenny's voice breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the sun rises in the morning, it is only because of men of goodwill. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's all there is between us and the Devil. They take each other in their arms, the wisdom of the ato age so simple, so tenuous, every human life hanging by su thread... yet a thread so powerful.  The CAMERA RISES FRO THEM, finding the OPEN WINDOW and the DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RED DOME OF NUCLEAR FIRE rising over Washington.  It roils the air in its expanding, blood-red glory. It is the sun.  The dawn in the East. PULL BACK THROUGH THE OPEN WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: into Kenny and Helen's bedroom.  And silence.  Kenny and Helen lie together on the bed.  The light burns into Kenn half-shut eye.  Kenny is only dimly conscious of the ligh meaning.  Until the PHONE SHRILLS downstairs. Kenny is instantly up, launched out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny snatches the RED PHONE from its hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny.  It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CHURCH BELLS TOLL in raucous celebration.  Kenny, Hel and the five O'DONNELL KIDS join the throng packing throu the doors to the church.  They're all smiling except Kenn who searches fro faces in the CROWD. And then he spots Bobby with his FAMILY.  Bobby grins at That makes Kenny grin back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Radio Moscow.  Moscow calling. But Kenny keeps looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following statement is the text of a letter from General Secretary Khruschev to President Kennedy. Kenny spots him emerging from the Presidential limo, surrounded by Secret Service Agents - John Kennedy.  His FAMILY also is with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I regard with respect and trust the statement you made in your message of 27 October 1962 that there would be no attack, no invasion of Cuba, and not only the part of the United States, but also on the part of the Western Hemisphere, as you said in your same message.  Then the motives which induced us to render assistance of such a kind to Cuba disappear... Kennedy, greeting well-wishers, a brilliant smile on his face, is carried through the crowd toward Kenny and the d of the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it is for this reason that we have instructed our officers - these missiles, as I already informed you are in the hands of Soviet officers to take appropriate measures to discontinue construction, dismantle them, and return them to the Soviet Union.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the base has been half-dismantled over night.  Fuel truck pull away, lumping down the makeshift dirt road.  Across site missiles are lowered, their nose cones being removed A MISSILE on its transporter, Technicians crawling all ov it, COVERING IT with a tarp. A massive Soviet Helicopter's rotors thunder as it lifts cargo crates swaying under it, a CLOUD OF DUST FROM ITS W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCOM laughing, celebrating, half-drunk already this Sund morning.  The President shushes the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Hey.  Okay, that's enough. The group quiets down.  The Presidents stares at them, ca firm.  They sober up quickly.  Kenny listens, expectant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want any gloating.  This is not a victory over the Soviets.  It's a victory with the Soviets. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want everyone to remember that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny rounds a corner.  McNamara, Bundy and McCone are talking, excited, hushed, standing to one side, down the hall.  Kenny eyes them as he draws closer, and then they notice he's approaching.  Bundy nods him over, confidenti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been talking.  We can play this big in '64.  It's the foreign policy trophy we've been waiting. Kenny sickens.  He tries to listen, but it all begins to blur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we can ride it all the way home next election.  Bet you're way ahead of us, eh? Bundy slaps Kenny on the back.  Kenny is pale.  Is what they're saying possible?  But Bundy and McCone are too wrapped up in their schemes to notice Kenny's distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've ordered crash reassessment of our major geopolitical hotspots.  We've got a lot of new clout, and we can run the table on the Soviets.  Middle East, Southeast Asia... And Kenny, sad, moved beyond all pity and loathing, reali it is possible.  They haven't gotten it.  He is speechles helplessly shaking his head.  Bundy finally sees somethin isn't right with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, O'Donnell? Kenny can't speak.  Can't find the words.  But tongue-tie finally manages:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand? McNamara and Bundy look at him funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understand what? Kenny just looks at them, eyes filled with sorrow.  They begin to feel uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun came up today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It shouldn't have.  But it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were lucky we were able to keep it under control. Kenny looks away, unable to bear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day the sun comes up... says something about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says what, Kenny? Kenny looks back at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something... amazing. They just stare at him.  And with secret smiles, superior smiles, they nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Ken.  I understand.  Feels good to win, doesn't it? But they don't understand, and together turn away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, Kenny. Kenny watches them, heads bowed in discussion, disappear the labyrinth of the West Wing.  Kenny turns his back on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President stands at his mirror, tying a bow tie to a for some Sunday special event.  Kenny gathers up his fold from nearby breakfast table. Kenny meets the President's gaze in the mirror, and the t men know they have been to the same mountaintop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny... A beat.  Kenny stands straight, ready for action, ready f some necessary thing.  Ready to go back into the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...never mind.  See you around, Kenny. Kenny starts to leave, but at the door, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... The President looks at him in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this was what we're here for. The President smiles an ever-so-faint smile.  Kenny turns leaves the room, vanishing, and as we HOLD on the empty doorway, the simple, whistled melody of O'DONNELL ABOO dr from the hallway beyond, becoming our END MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Shortly after the crisis President Kennedy ordered a reassessment of U.S.-Soviet relations, ushering a brief t in the Cold War.  During this time, the Washington-Moscow hotline was installed to ensure that in a future crisis, miscommunication would not lead to nuclear war. The President was assassinated on November 22nd, a year a the crisis ended.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUPER
dialogues.text: Bobby Kennedy ran for president in 1968.  After winning t California primary, he called Kenny from the Ambassador H in Los Angeles and told him, "I finally feel like I'm out from under my brother's shadow." Bobby was assassinated minutes later.

dialogues.speaker: THEN SUPER
dialogues.text: The members of EXCOM continued  to serve with distinction government in various capacities over the next three deca As Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense, Robert McNamara urged containment of the Soviet threat in every theatre o conflict around the world.  He ultimately advised Preside Johnson to increase the U.S. military commitment to one o these minor backwater conflicts: Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: AND FINALLY SUPER
dialogues.text: Kenny O'Donnell witnessed the President's assassination f the car behind.  He went on to head the Peace Platform at 1968 Democratic National  Convention, fighting to end the Vietnam War.  He died in 1977.
